revision.comment: He didn't get to Everton until about nine years after he started playing professionally. This isn't "the beginning" of his career.
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Marco Materazzi | image = Marco Materazzi - Inter Mailand (1).jpg | image_size = 230 | caption = Materazzi in 2009 | fullname = Marco Materazzi | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1973|8|19|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Lecce]], Italy | height = {{height|m=1.93}} | position = [[Defender (association football)#Centre-back|Centre back]] | currentclub = | youthyears1 = 1988–1990 |youthclubs1 = [[S.S. Lazio|Lazio]] | youthyears2 = 1990–1991 |youthclubs2 = [[A.C.R. Messina|Messina Peloro]] | youthyears3 = 1991–1993 |youthclubs3 = Tor di Quinto | years1 = 1990–1991 |clubs1 = [[A.C.R. Messina|Messina]] |caps1 = 1 |goals1 = 0 | years2 = 1991–1993 |clubs2 = Tor di Quinto |caps2 = 12 |goals2 = 0 | years3 = 1993–1994 |clubs3 = [[S.C. Marsala|Marsala]] |caps3 = 25 |goals3 = 4 | years4 = 1994–1995 |clubs4 = [[Trapani Calcio|Trapani]] |caps4 = 13 |goals4 = 2 | years5 = 1995–1998 |clubs5 = [[Perugia Calcio|Perugia]] |caps5 = 47 |goals5 = 7 | years6 = 1996–1997 |clubs6 = → [[Carpi FC 1909|Carpi]] (loan) |caps6 = 18 |goals6 = 7 | years7 = 1998–1999 |clubs7 = [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] |caps7 = 25 |goals7 = 1 | years8 = 1999–2001 |clubs8 = [[Perugia Calcio|Perugia]] |caps8 = 51 |goals8 = 15 | years9 = 2001–2011 |clubs9 = [[Inter Milan|Internazionale]] |caps9 = 184 |goals9 = 18 | years10 = 2014–2016 |clubs10 = [[Chennaiyin FC|Chennaiyin]] |caps10 = 7 |goals10 = 0 | totalcaps = 405 | totalgoals = 55 | nationalyears1 = 2001–2008 | nationalteam1 = [[Italy national football team|Italy]] | nationalcaps1 = 41 | nationalgoals1 = 2 | manageryears1 = 2014–2016 | managerclubs1 = [[Chennaiyin FC|Chennaiyin]] | club-update = | nationalteam-update = | medaltemplates = {{MedalCountry|{{ITA}}}} {{MedalSport |Association football}} {{MedalCompetition |[[FIFA World Cup]]}} {{Medal|Winner|[[2006 FIFA World Cup|Germany 2006]]|}} }}
'''Marco Materazzi''', <small>[[Order of Merit of the Italian Republic|Ufficiale OMRI]]</small> ({{IPA-it|ˈmarko mateˈrattsi}}; born 19 August 1973) is an [[Italians|Italian]] former professional [[Association football|footballer]] and [[Association football manager|manager]].
Early in his career, Materazzi played with various Italian teams in [[Serie B]] and [[Serie C]], and with [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] in the [[Premier League]]. He spent two periods with [[Perugia Calcio|Perugia]] (1995–98 and 1999–2001) and signed for [[Inter Milan|Internazionale]] in 2001 for €10 million. At club level, he won a number of major honors with Inter, including five [[Serie A]] league titles in a row from 2006 to 2010, one [[UEFA Champions League]], one [[FIFA Club World Cup]], four [[Coppa Italia]] titles, and the [[Supercoppa Italiana]] four times.<ref>The Matrix – Marco Materazzi: {{cite web|url=http://lazymanscalcio.tumblr.com/post/18215957095/the-matrix |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-04-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203063129/http://lazymanscalcio.tumblr.com/post/18215957095/the-matrix |archivedate=3 December 2013 |df= }}</ref>
Materazzi earned 41 caps for Italy from his debut in 2001 until 2008, playing in two World Cups and two European Championships. He was one of the key players in the [[2006 FIFA World Cup Final]] against France, as he scored Italy's goal and later, in extra time, he received a headbutt from [[Zinedine Zidane]], who was punished with a red card.<ref name="World Cup"/> Italy then went on to win the World Cup in a penalty shoot-out, during which Materazzi scored again.
A controversial and provocative figure in football, he was known for his very physical and aggressive style of play as a [[Defender (association football)|defender]], as well as his tight marking and strong, harsh tackling, which led him to receive more than 60 yellow cards and 25 red cards throughout his playing career.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.serpentsofmadonnina.com/2011/7/18/3211758/marco-materazzi-a-bandieria-among-bandierie|title=Marco Materazzi: A Bandieria Among Bandierie|publisher=Serpents of Madonnina|date=18 July 2011|accessdate=19 October 2018}}</ref> Due to his temper, and his commitment to rash, heavy challenges, he has been involved in several altercations with other players during matches,<ref name="Materazzi">{{cite web|last1=Cazullo|first1=Aldo|title=Materazzi|url=http://archiviostorico.corriere.it/2006/luglio/11/Materazzi_co_9_060711008.shtml|website=www.corriere.it|publisher=Il Corriere della Sera|accessdate=14 September 2014}}</ref> drawing comparisons with retired defender [[Pasquale Bruno]].<ref>{{cite web|author1=Emanuele Gamba|title="O' animale resto sempre io una volta aspettai Lerda..."|trans-title="I'm still the animal once I waited for Lerda..."|url=http://www.repubblica.it/2004/b/sezioni/sport/calcio/serie_a/brunotunnel/brunotunnel/brunotunnel.html|publisher=La Repubblica|accessdate=4 May 2015|language=Italian|date=3 February 2004}}</ref> ''[[The Times]]'' placed Materazzi at number 45 in their list of the 50 hardest football players in history.<ref>{{cite web|title=Top 50 Hardest Footballers |url=http://www.empireonline.com/forum/printable.asp?m=1554851 |accessdate=14 September 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151019002225/http://www.empireonline.com/forum/printable.asp?m=1554851 |archivedate=19 October 2015 |df= }}</ref>
==Club career== ===Early career=== Materazzi began his footballing career with the [[S.S. Lazio|Lazio]] and then the [[F.C. Messina Peloro|Messina Peloro]] youth teams from 1990 to 1991.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.alpha59.it/news/50/la-carriera-di-marco-materazzi.html|title=LA CARRIERA DI MARCO MATERAZZI|date=3 March 2018|publisher=alpha59.it}}</ref> He spent his early career in the lower divisions of Italian football, with amateur side Tor di Quinto (1991–92), [[Serie C]]2 team [[S.C. Marsala 1912|Marsala]] (1993–94), and Serie C1 [[A.S.D. Trapani Calcio|Trapani]] (1994–95), where he narrowly missed a historic promotion to [[Serie B]] after losing a promotion playoff to [[S.S. Gualdo|Gualdo]]. [[Serie B]] squad [[Perugia Calcio]] signed Materazzi for the first time in 1995,<ref name="Early life"/> but he spent a part of the 1996–97 season in Serie C with [[Carpi F.C. 1909|Carpi]].
He then spent 1998–99 with [[Everton F.C.|Everton]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.toffeeweb.com/players/profiles/Materazzi.php|title=Marco Materazzi central defender|publisher=ToffeeWeb.com|accessdate=14 October 2018}}</ref> where he was sent off three times in just 27 games, and scored twice, against [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] in the league<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football-barmby-sparks-everton-deluge-1071633.html|title=Barmby sparks Everton deluge|publisher=[[The Independent]]|author=Neil Bramwell|location=London|date=17 February 1999|accessdate=9 November 2009}}</ref> and [[Huddersfield Town F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] in the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football-dacourt-drives-everton-through-1200301.html|title=Dacourt drives Everton through|publisher=The Independent|author=Phill Shaw|location=London|date=23 September 1998|accessdate=9 November 2009}}</ref><ref name=gazzetta/>
He then returned to Perugia in 1999 and scored 12 goals, including 7 from penalties in the [[2000–01 Serie A|2000–01 season]], breaking [[Daniel Passarella]]'s Serie A record of most goals by a defender in one season.<ref name=gazzetta/>
===Internazionale=== ====2001–2004: Debut and controversies==== [[File:Materazzi maglia.jpg|thumb|left|250px|Materazzi's number 23 shirt]] Materazzi was signed by [[Inter Milan|Internazionale]] in July 2001 for €10 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www2.raisport.rai.it/news/sport/calcio/200107/17/3b54a7f001fa6/|title=Difensore cannoniere all'Inter|trans-title=The goalscoring defender at Inter|publisher=Rai Sport|language=Italian|date=17 July 2001|accessdate=13 October 2018}}</ref><ref>[http://www.sportspundit.com/soccer/players/107-marco-materazzi Marco Materazzi – News, Stats and Info About the Soccer Player<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> He took squad number 23 and made his competitive debut for the club on 26 August in the opening [[2001–02 Serie A|championship]] match against [[A.C. Perugia|Perugia]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.repubblica.it/online/calcio_partite/inteperu/inteperu/inteperu.html|title=Kallon e Vieri da favola, decolla l'Inter di Cuper|trans-title=Kallon and Vieri fairytale, Cuper's Inter takes off|publisher=Repubblica.it|language=Italian|date=26 August 2001|accessdate=13 October 2018}}</ref> Materazzi's first goal for Inter came only in his second appearance, netting inside 10 minutes in a 2–2 draw at [[Parma Calcio 1913|Parma]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.repubblica.it/online/calcio_partite/parmainter/parmainter/parmainter.html|title=Il Tardini si conferma, campo stregato per l'Inter|trans-title=The Tardini is confirmed as cursed field for Inter|publisher=Repubblica.it|language=Italian|date=9 September 2001|accessdate=13 October 2018}}</ref> He also played eight time in the [[2001–02 UEFA Cup|season]]'s [[UEFA Europa League|UEFA Cup]], with the debuting match coming on 20 September in the 3–0 win versus [[Romania]]'s [[SR Brașov|Brașov]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.uefa.com/uefaeuropaleague/season=2001/matches/round=1551/match=68273/index.html|title=Internazionale 2-0 Brașov|publisher=UEFA.com|date=20 September 2001|accessdate=13 October 2018}}</ref>
Materazzi played 23 matches in league, including the final decisive match versus [[S.S. Lazio|Lazio]] which lost Inter the championship title;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archiviostorico.gazzetta.it/2002/maggio/06/Inter_paga_grande_illusione_ga_0_0205061470.shtml|title=L' Inter paga la grande illusione|trans-title=Inter pays great illusion|publisher=La Gazzetta dello Sport|language=Italian|date=6 May 2002|accessdate=13 October 2018}}</ref> he was a protagonist of a controversy episode following the final whistle as he was included in a heated discussion with the opposite players which also went to physical confrontation.<ref name="Materazzi23">{{cite web|url=http://www.repubblica.it/online/calcio/materazzi/materazzi/materazzi.html|title=Materazzi, lite con Nesta: "Vi ho fatto vincere il titolo"|trans-title=Materazzi, quarrel with Nesta: "I won you the title"|publisher=Repubblica.it|language=Italian|date=6 May 2002|accessdate=13 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://archiviostorico.gazzetta.it/2002/maggio/06/Moratti_prende_con_Lazio_ga_0_0205061424.shtml|title=Moratti se la prende con la Lazio|trans-title=Moratti gets angry with Lazio|publisher=La Gazzetta dello Sport|language=Italian|date=6 May 2002|accessdate=13 October 2018}}</ref> He was caught by the cameras shouting at Lazio captain [[Alessandro Nesta]], saying: "I won you the title", in reference to Perugia's win over [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]] in 2000 which lead Lazio to the title.<ref name="Materazzi23"/>
In the [[2002–03 Inter Milan season|following season]], Materazzi made 33 appearances across all competitions, including 13 in [[UEFA Champions League]], where he played his first match on 14 August 2002 in a goalless draw against [[Sporting CP]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/season=2002/matches/round=1635/match=70011/index.html|title=Sporting CP 0-0 Internazionale|publisher=UEFA.com|date=14 August 2002|accessdate=13 October 2018}}</ref>
Materazzi's [[2003–04 Inter Milan season|2003–04 season]] was highlighted by injuries, such as the one he suffered on 25 November during the 5–1 home loss to [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] in [[2003–04 UEFA Champions League group stage#Group B|UEFA Champions League group stage]] which kept him out of action for two months.<ref name="Suspension">{{cite web|url=https://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/news/newsid=129970.html#inter+miss+materazzi|title=Inter to miss Materazzi|publisher=UEFA.com|date=27 November 2003|accessdate=15 October 2018}}</ref> He was in the center of a controversy again in the beginning of 2004 for aggression towards Siena player [[Bruno Cirillo]]. This happened on 1 February in a match which was won 4–0 by Inter.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legaseriea.it/it/serie-a/match-report/2003-04/UNICO/UNI/19/INTSIE|title=Inter 4-0 Robur Siena|publisher=Lega Serie A|language=Italian|date=1 February 2004|accessdate=14 October 2018}}</ref> Materazzi (who did not play in the match) confronted Cirillo in the dressing rooms and begun spewing insults towards him. He also punched him in the face, fracturing his lip.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archiviostorico.gazzetta.it/2004/febbraio/02/Materazzi_dato_pugno__ga_10_040202066.shtml|title=«Materazzi mi ha dato un pugno»|trans-title=«Materazzi gave me a punch»|publisher=La Gazzetta dello Sport|language=Italian|author1=Graziano Mirko|author2=Capone Antonello|date=2 February 2004|accessdate=14 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.repubblica.it/2004/b/sezioni/sport/calcio/serie_a/matestangata/matestangata/matestangata.html|title=Cirillo: "Prima gli insulti, poi il pugno", Materazzi rischia una lunga squalifica|trans-title=Cirillo: "First the insults, then the punch", Materazzi risks a long disqualification|publisher=Reppublica.it|language=Italian|location=Milan|date=2 February 2004|accessdate=14 October 2018}}</ref> After the incident was denounced, the sports judge Maurizio Laudi suspended Materazzi until 29 March,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gazzetta.it/primi_piani/calcio/2004/pp_1.0.289804258.shtml|title=Materazzi fermo fino al 29 marzo|trans-title=Materazzi suspended until 29 March|publisher=La Gazzetta dello Sport|language=Italian|location=Milan|date=3 February 2004|accessdate=14 October 2018}}</ref> meaning that he will miss eight club matches and one international match.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.eurosport.com/football/campionato-italiano/2003-2004/materazzi-in-brawl_sto541746/story.shtml|title=Materazzi faces ban for post-match brawl|publisher=Eurosport|work=Reuters|date=2 February 2004|accessdate=14 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://theworldgame.sbs.com.au/materazzi-i-was-provoked|title=Materazzi: I was provoked|publisher=The World Game|date=22 April 2014|accessdate=14 October 2018}}</ref> In addition to his domestic suspension, Materazzi was also suspended by [[UEFA]] for two [[UEFA Cup]] games.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.uefa.com/uefaeuropaleague/news/newsid=147670.html|title=Materazzi suspended for UEFA Cup|publisher=UEFA.com|date=24 February 2004|accessdate=15 October 2018}}</ref> Inter was also fined with €5,000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.repubblica.it/2004/b/sezioni/sport/calcio/serie_a/marzo29/marzo29/marzo29.html|title=Materazzi fermo fino ad aprile, 5000 euro di multa all'Inter|trans-title=Materazzi suspended until April, 5000 euro fine for Inter|publisher=Reppublica.it|language=Italian|date=3 February 2004|accessdate=14 October 2018}}</ref> Materazzi later apologized for the incident, saying that he "behaved badly" and "reacted in a bad way", also adding that he would not appeal the suspension.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.skysports.com/football/news/11860/2290669/materazzi-apologises-to-cirillo|title=Materazzi apologises to Cirillo|publisher=Sky Sports|author=Nadia Carminati|accessdate=14 October 2018}}</ref>
====2004–2008: Domestic success under Mancini==== In July 2004, at the start of [[2004–05 Inter Milan season|2004–05 season]], Inter bench was entrusted to manager [[Roberto Mancini]], with whom – in the first season – Materazzi lost his place in the starting lineup.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ricerca.repubblica.it/repubblica/archivio/repubblica/2005/01/07/mancini-ok-materazzi-non-voleva-insultare-me.html|title=Mancini: Ok Materazzi, non voleva insultare me|trans-title=Mancini: Ok Materazzi, he did not want to insult me|publisher=Repubblica.it|language=Italian|location=Livorno|date=7 January 2005|accessdate=15 October 2018}}</ref> In the next season he played more,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://it.eurosport.com/calcio/amichevoli/2005/funziona-la-doppia-inter_sto747019/story.shtml|title=Funziona la doppia Inter|trans-title=Inter double works|publisher=Eurosport|language=Italian|date=27 July 2005|accessdate=15 October 2018}}</ref> and was the only Italian to score a goal for the club that season. On 5 March 2006, Materazzi scored a 89th-minute header at [[A.S. Roma|Roma]] to rescue his side a point and to break the hosts' record of 11 consecutive victories.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.repubblica.it/2006/c/sezioni/sport/calcio/serie_a/28giornata/romainter/romainter.html|title=Materazzi beffa la Roma al 90', Sfuma la dodicesima vittoria|trans-title=Materazzi mocked Roma at 90 ', Wastes the twelfth victory|publisher=Repubblica.it|language=Italian|location=Rome|date=5 March 2006|accessdate=15 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.inter.it/en/news/22097/materazzi-earns-inter-point-in-rome|title=Materazzi earns Inter point in Rome|publisher=inter.it|date=5 March 2006|accessdate=15 October 2018}}</ref> He finished the 2005–06 season by totaling 39 appearances across all competitions.
Materazzi signed a new contract in August 2006 which kept him at [[San Siro]] until June 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2006-08-04/materazzi-extends-inter-contract/1230522|title=Materazzi extends Inter contract|publisher=ABC News|date=3 August 2006|accessdate=13 October 2018}}</ref> At the end of the year he was a nominee for [[UEFA Team of the Year]] along with teammate [[Fabio Grosso]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.inter.it/en/news/24907/uefa-team-of-2006-grosso-matrix-on-list|title=UEFA team of 2006: Grosso, Matrix on list|publisher=UEFA.com|date=6 December 2006|accessdate=15 October 2018}}</ref> The [[2006–07 Serie A|2006–07 season]] saw him scoring 10 goals, thus being the top scoring defender of Serie A.<ref>[http://soccernet.espn.go.com/stats/scorers/_/league/ita.1/year/2006/italian-serie-a?cc=5901 Italian Serie A Goal Scoring Leaders – 2006–07 – ESPN FC<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> He notably scored in the 4–3 win in [[Derby della Madonnina]] against [[A.C. Milan|Milan]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gazzetta.it/Calcio/Squadre/Milan/Primo_Piano/2006/10_Ottobre/28/prederby.shtml|title=Milan-Inter 3-4|publisher=La Gazzetta dello Sport|language=Italian|location=Milan|date=28 October 2006|accessdate=14 October 2018}}</ref> an overhead kick versus [[A.C.R. Messina|Messina]] and a brace away to [[AC Siena|Siena]] on 23 April which won the club's 15th league title with five games remaining.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.repubblica.it/2006/12/sezioni/sport/calcio/serie_a/giornata-16/inter-messina/inter-messina.html|title=Materazzi inventa la rovesciata, l'Inter firma un bel record|trans-title=Materazzi invents the overhead kick, Inter sign a good record|publisher=Repubblica.it|language=Italian|location=Milan|date=17 December 2006|accessdate=14 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Andersson|first=Astrid|title=Materazzi secures early title for Inter|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/european/2311629/Materazzi-secures-early-title-for-Inter.html|accessdate=23 April 2014|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=23 April 2007}}</ref> For his performances, Materazzi was voted the [[Serie A Defender of the Year]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.inter.it/en/news/28510/materazzi-wins-footballers-association-award|title=Materazzi wins footballers' association award|publisher=inter.it|date=29 January 2008|accessdate=15 October 2018}}</ref>
[[File:Marco Materazzi - Inter Mailand (2).jpg|thumb|right|240px|Materazzi during a training session]] Materazzi missed the first part of [[2007–08 Inter Milan season|2007–08 season]] due to an injury suffered whilst on international duty which forced him to be sidelined until November 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.repubblica.it/2007/11/sezioni/sport/calcio/serie_a/giornata-13/inter-atalanta/inter-atalanta.html|title=Inter, Suazo e Cruz fanno tutto facile, Poi l'Atalanta mette paura: 2-1|trans-title=Inter, Suazo and Cruz make everything easy, then Atalanta puts fear: 2-1|publisher=Reppublica.it|language=Italian|location=Milan|date=24 November 2007|accessdate=14 October 2018}}</ref> Later in February of the following year, Materazzi gave a poor display in the first leg of [[2007–08 UEFA Champions League]] first knockout round against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]], receiving a red card in the 30th minute, as Inter lost 2–0 at [[Anfield]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.skysports.com/football/liverpool-vs-inter/97342|title=Late show eases Rafa pressure|publisher=Sky Sports|author=James Dall|date=20 February 2008|accessdate=14 October 2018}}</ref> His performance was criticised by his teammates after the end of the match.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/2292303/Inter-Milan-players-turn-on-Marco-Materazzi.html|title=Inter Milan players turn on Marco Materazzi|publisher=Telegraph.co.uk|author=Malcolm Moore|location=Rome|date=21 February 2008|accessdate=14 October 2018}}</ref> Later on throughout the season, during a 2–2 draw against [[Robur Siena|Siena]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/it/news/2/serie-a/2008/05/11/692352/inter-siena-2-2-nerazzurri-raggiunti-per-due-volte-e|title=Inter-Siena 2-2: Nerazzurri raggiunti per due volte. E Materazzi sciupa il penalty-scudetto|trans-title=Inter-Siena 2-2: Nerazzurri reached twice. And Materazzi wastes the penalty-Scudetto|publisher=Goal.com|date=11 May 2008|accessdate=14 October 2018}}</ref> Materazzi argued with striker [[Julio Ricardo Cruz]] on who to take a penalty kick.<ref name="The penalty"/> Eventually it was Materazzi who took it but his attempt was easily saved by [[Alex Manninger]].<ref name="The penalty"/> It was his first miss since 2001. The draw spoiled Inter's chances of winning the title with one game to spare. After the match, the choice to take the penalty was criticized by manager [[Roberto Mancini]] while Materazzi himself apologized, stating that it should have been Cruz the one to take it.<ref name="The penalty">{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idINIndia-33527620080512|title=Inter's Materazzi apologises for taking penalty|publisher=Reuters.com|date=12 May 2008|accessdate=14 October 2018}}</ref> Inter eventually won the championship for the third consecutive time after defeating Parma 2–0 in the last matchday with Materazzi playing full-90 minutes.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2008/may/19/internazionale.europeanfootball|title=Inter's blushes spared as Ibrahimovic earns his redemption|publisher=The Guardian|date=19 May 2008|accessdate=18 May 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2008/05/18/italy/serie-a/parma-fc/fc-internazionale-milano/501458/|title=Parma vs. Internazionale 0 – 2|publisher=Soccerway|date=18 May 2008|accessdate=14 October 2018}}</ref> He concluded the season with 23 Serie A appearances, 4 Coppa Italia appearances, 1 Supercoppa Italiana appearance and 3 UEFA Champions League appearances for a total of 33 appearances.
====2008–2011: Final years and more glory==== The summer of 2008 saw the arrival of Portuguese manager [[José Mourinho]] who did not saw Materazzi as the first choice in defence, relegating him to the bench.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.repubblica.it/2009/05/speciale/altri/inter-vince-scudetto/pagellone-scudetto/pagellone-scudetto.html|title=Julio Cesar e Maicon fondamentali, Cambiasso decisivo, bene Santon|trans-title=Júlio César and Maicon fundamental, Cambiasso decisive, Santon good|publisher=Repubblica.it|language=Italian|author=Gianni Piva|date=17 May 2009|accessdate=14 October 2018}}</ref> Apart from that, his season was also marred by injuries, which reduced his league tally to only 8 appearances.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/1707/inter/2008/12/10/1004791/marco-materazzi-fractures-cheekbone|title=Inter Defender Materazzi Fractures Cheekbone|publisher=Goal.com|author=Adam Scime|date=10 December 2008|accessdate=14 October 2018}}</ref> He scored his first UEFA Champions League goal on 4 November in a 3–3 draw at [[Anorthosis Famagusta FC|Anorthosis]] in the [[2008–09 UEFA Champions League group stage#Group B|Group B]] matchday 4.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.inter.it/en/news/30190/champions-league-anorthosis-3-3-inter|title=Champions League: Anorthosis 3-3 Inter|publisher=inter.it|date=4 November 2008|accessdate=14 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/1716/champions-league/2008/11/04/948412/player-ratings-anorthosis-3-3-inter|title=Player Ratings: Anorthosis 3-3 Inter|publisher=Goal.com|author=Anthony Sormani|date=4 November 2008|accessdate=14 October 2018}}</ref> Materazzi won his 4th [[Serie A|championship]] on 17 May 2009 following Inter's 3–0 defeat of Siena.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2009/may/18/serie-a-inter-jose-mourinho|title=Jose Mourinho makes Ibrahimovic sweat for his goal as Inter celebrate scudetto in style|publisher=The Guardian|author=Paolo Bandini|date=18 May 2009|accessdate=14 October 2018}}</ref> Despite playing rarely, he was still praised by president [[Massimo Moratti]] who said that Materazzi "always played well whenever he was called upon last season" while manager Mourinho stated that he wanted to have Materazzi in his team.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.uefa.com/news/newsid=837298.html#/evergreen+materazzi+extends+inter+stay|title=Evergreen Materazzi extends Inter stay|publisher=UEFA.com|date=10 June 2009|accessdate=15 October 2018}}</ref>
[[File:Marco Materazzi - Inter Mailand (3).jpg|thumb|left|200px|Materazzi in action for Inter]] In June 2009, Materazzi was handed a new deal by Inter until June 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2009/SPORT/football/07/02/inter.milan.materazzi.motta/index.html|title=Veteran Materazzi handed new Inter deal|publisher=CNN|date=2 July 2009|accessdate=13 October 2018}}</ref> He was used sparingly during the [[2009–10 Inter Milan season|2009–10 season]], making 20 appearances in all competitions. In January 2010, he underwent arthroscopic surgery to repair damage to the medial meniscus in his right knee which kept him sidelined for one month.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/news/newsid=941521.html|title=Materazzi leaves hole in Inter defence|publisher=UEFA.com|date=11 January 2010|accessdate=13 October 2018}}</ref> Materazzi was an injury-time substitute for Inter in the [[2010 UEFA Champions League Final]] against [[FC Bayern Munich|Bayern Munich]], replacing [[Diego Milito]] who scored both of their goals in the 2–0 victory in [[Madrid]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.inter.it/en/news/33968/champions-league-final-bayern-munich-0-2-inter|title=Champions League final: Bayern Munich 0-2 Inter|publisher=inter.it|date=22 May 2010|accessdate=13 October 2018}}</ref> In addition to that, Inter also clinched the ''[[Scudetto]]'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en-us/news/86/italy/2010/05/16/1927554/siena-0-1-inter-diego-milito-secures-scudetto-for-nerazzurri|title=Siena 0-1 Inter: Diego Milito Secures Scudetto For Nerazzurri|publisher=Goal.com|author=Adam Scime|date=16 May 2010|accessdate=13 October 2018}}</ref> for the fifth season in a row,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2010/may/16/inter-milan-win-serie-a|title=Internazionale take fifth successive Serie A title with win at Siena|publisher=The Guardian|date=16 May 2010|accessdate=13 October 2018}}</ref> and [[2010 Coppa Italia Final|Coppa Italia]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en-india/news/2177/coppa-italia/2010/05/06/1910660/inter-1-0-roma-diego-milito-wins-the-coppa-italia-for-the|title=Inter 1-0 Roma: Diego Milito Wins The Coppa Italia For The Nerazzurri|publisher=Goal.com|author=Subhankar Mondal|date=6 May 2010|accessdate=13 October 2018}}</ref> to complete the [[Treble (association football)|Treble]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/news/newsid=1490968.html|title=Inter join exclusive treble club|publisher=UEFA.com|date=22 May 2010|accessdate=13 October 2018}}</ref>
He begun the [[2010–11 Inter Milan season|2010–11 season]] by coming on in the last minutes of a 3–1 home win over [[A.S. Roma|Roma]] in the [[Supercoppa Italiana]] match.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.uefa.com/memberassociations/association=ita/news/newsid=1516658.html|title=Two-goal Eto'o fires Inter to more glory|publisher=UEFA.com|date=22 August 2010|accessdate=14 October 2018}}</ref> Materazzi's first league match of the season came later in November where he started in the derby against Milan due to the absence of [[Walter Samuel]]; he conceded a penalty in 4th minute for fouling [[Zlatan Ibrahimović]] and was later sent to hospital after a receiving a kung-fu kick in the stomach by the Swede.<ref name="Injury1">{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/3194/video/2010/11/15/2214843/video-zlatan-ibrahimovic-sends-marco-materazzi-to-hospital|title=VIDEO: Zlatan Ibrahimovic Sends Marco Materazzi To Hospital With A Kung-Fu Kick|publisher=Goal.com|date=15 November 2010|accessdate=14 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/fifa-world-ranking/news/y=2010/m=11/news=materazzi-taken-hospital-after-ibra-clash-1334644.html|title=Materazzi taken to hospital after Ibra clash|publisher=FIFA.com|date=15 November 2010|accessdate=14 October 2018}}</ref> Inter lost the match 1–0.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2010/11/14/italy/serie-a/fc-internazionale-milano/ac-milan/990066/|title=Internazionale vs. Milan 0 – 1|publisher=Soccerway|date=14 November 2010|accessdate=14 October 2018}}</ref> Following the end of the match, manager [[Rafael Benítez]] calmed the situation by stating that Materazzi's injury "doesn't seem serious".<ref name="Injury1"/> He returend in action two weeks later by playing full-90 minutes in a 5–2 home win over Parma.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.inter.it/en/news/35129|title=Inter-Parma: 5-2, Stankovic starts and finishes|publisher=inter.it|date=29 November 2010|accessdate=14 October 2018}}</ref> In December, Materazzi was included in Inter's squad for [[2010 FIFA Club World Cup]], remaining on the bench as Inter won their 5th title of the year.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/clubworldcup/matches/round=254488/match=300140542/match-report.html|title=Internazionale on top of the world|publisher=FIFA.com|date=18 December 2010|accessdate=14 October 2018}}</ref>
Materazzi left the club in July 2011 after not being offered a new contract, having played around 270 games for the club and winning 15 trophies,<ref name="inter.it"/> and shortly after, announced his retirement from the sport.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sportsnet.ca/soccer/materazzi-inter/|title=Report: Materazzi leaving Inter after season|publisher=Sportsnet.ca|date=20 June 2011|accessdate=13 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://intermilanfansworldwide.wordpress.com/2011/07/21/a-salute-to-marco-materazzi-tutti-pazzi-per-materazzi/|title=A Salute to Marco Materazzi|publisher=Inter fans|date=21 July 2011|accessdate=13 October 2018}}</ref> He was later appointed in the role of ambassador to Inter. Later, Materazzi accused manager [[Leonardo Araújo|Leonardo]] of "stabbed him in the back" and the reason of his departure from Inter,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/10/italian-football/2011/07/20/2583194/marco-materazzi-hits-out-at-former-inter-coaches-leonardo-rafael-|title=Marco Materazzi hits out at former Inter coaches Leonardo & Rafael Benitez|publisher=Goal.com|author=Salvatore Landolina|date=20 July 2011|accessdate=14 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/10/italy/2012/04/22/3053177/leonardo-stabbed-me-in-the-back-two-or-three-times-claims|title=Leonardo stabbed me in the back two or three times, claims Materazzi|publisher=Goal.com|author=Mark Doyle|date=22 April 2012|accessdate=14 October 2018}}</ref> and also threw accusations to president Massimo Moratti of not having defended him against Leonardo.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archiviostorico.gazzetta.it/2011/luglio/20/MATERAZZI_tradito_Leonardo_ora_Inter_ga_10_110720426.shtml|title=MATERAZZI «Io tradito da Leonardo ma ora l' Inter l' ho tatuata sul cuore»|trans-title=Materazzi «I was betrayed by Leonardo and now I have Inter tattoed in my heart»|publisher=La Gazzetta dello Sport|author=Elefante Andrea|date=20 July 2011|accessdate=14 October 2018}}</ref>
===Chennaiyin FC=== [[File:Marco materazzi CFC 2014-2016.jpg|thumb|210px|right|Materazzi during his time with Chennaiyin FC.]] On 22 September 2014, Materazzi was signed as the player-manager of [[Chennaiyin FC]] in the [[2014 Indian Super League season|inaugural season]] of the [[Indian Super League]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Fans accord Marco Materazzi a warm welcome|url=http://www.indiansuperleague.com/news/389-fans-accord-marco-materazzi-a-warm-welcome|publisher=ISL|accessdate=22 September 2014}}</ref> Materazzi signed a two-season contract with Chennaiyin for $1 million (USD) every season.<ref>{{cite web|title=Elano is Chennai´s Marquee|url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/sport/Elano-is-Chennais-Marquee/2014/09/19/article2438488.ece|publisher=INDIAN Express|accessdate=19 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Marco Materazzi to manage Chennai Titans|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/football/indian-super-league/top-stories/Marco-Materazzi-to-manage-Chennai-Titans/articleshow/42334829.cms|publisher=Times of India |accessdate=12 September 2014}}</ref> Materazzi did not choose himself to play in their opening match, a 2–1 victory at [[FC Goa]] on 15 October courtesy of a free kick from marquee player and former Brazil international [[Elano]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Raj|first1=Rohan|title=ISL: Record-breaking Chennaiyin FC romp to 2–1 win over FC Goa|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/isl-chennaiyin-fc-vs-fc-goa-live-indian-super-league-match-4-nehru-stadium/1/395917.html|accessdate=15 October 2014|work=[[India Today]]|date=15 October 2014}}</ref> Six days later in his first home game, Chennaiyin defeated the [[Kerala Blasters]] 2–1, but four days after that he lost for the first time, 1–4 to the [[Delhi Dynamos]]. In the club's fourth match of the season, he selected himself to play for the first time, starting in a 5–1 win over [[Mumbai City FC|Mumbai City]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Suchindran|first1=Aravind|title=Elano, Mendoza shine as Chennai trounce Mumbai 5–1|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/football/indian-super-league/top-stories/Elano-Mendoza-shine-as-Chennai-trounce-Mumbai-5-1/articleshow/44967343.cms|accessdate=31 October 2014|work=[[The Times of India]]|date=28 October 2014}}</ref> On 28 November, he brought his former international defensive partner Alessandro Nesta out of retirement to play for Chennaiyin until the end of the season.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Davies|first1=Jack|title=Alessandro Nesta comes out of retirement to join Indian Super League side Chennaiyin|url=http://www.goal.com/en-gb/news/2892/transfer-zone/2014/11/28/6601801/alessandro-nesta-comes-out-of-retirement-to-join-indian|accessdate=30 November 2014|work=Goal.com|date=28 November 2014}}</ref> Chennaiyin finished the 14-game regular season in first place in the league, with Materazzi having made 6 appearances. In the [[2014 Indian Super League finals|end-of-season play-offs]], the team were eliminated in extra time in the semi-finals by the [[Kerala Blasters]].
At the end of the [[2015 Indian Super League season|2015 season]], in which Materazzi led Chennaiyin to the Indian Super League championship, his contract ended.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ready to extend contract: Materazzi|url=http://www.thehindu.com/sport/football/indian-super-league-2015-finals-isl-2015-finals-ready-to-extend-contract-chennaiyin-fc-head-coach-materazzi/article8011414.ece|accessdate=21 December 2015|work=The Hindu|date=21 December 2015}}</ref> After the conclusion of the [[2016 Indian Super League season|2016 season]], it was announced that Materazzi would not return to the club for 2017.<ref>{{cite news|title=Chennaiyin Statement|url=http://chennaiyinfc.com/chennaiyin-fc-club-statement-on-marco-materazzi/|accessdate=6 March 2017|work=Chennaiyin FC|date=6 March 2017}}</ref>
==International career== ===Debut and 2002 World Cup=== Materazzi made his debut for the [[Italy national football team|Italy national team]] on 25 April 2001, in a 1–0 friendly match victory against [[South Africa national football team|South Africa]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/africa/1294939.stm|title=Italy edge out South Africa|publisher=BBC Sport|date=25 April 2001|accessdate=20 October 2018}}</ref> He made two appearances in the qualifying campaign against Georgia and Hungary. In the final tournament of the [[2002 FIFA World Cup]], Materazzi was used as a reserve player to back up Alessandro Nesta and Fabio Cannavaro. He made only one appearance by coming on as a substitute for Nesta in the [[2002 FIFA World Cup Group G|2–1 loss]] to [[Croatia national football team|Croatia]] in the group stage but soon in the 90th minute Materazzi played a floating ball over the top from just over half way to [[Filippo Inzaghi|Inzaghi]] but everyone missed the ball and it rolled in the back of the net but the goal was disallowed after referee [[Graham Poll]] claimed that Inzaghi had grabbed an opponent's shirt.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2002/jun/09/worldcupfootball2002.sport23|title=Italy are offline|publisher=The Guardian|author1=Simon Kuper|date=9 June 2002|accessdate=14 December 2015}}</ref> Materazzi was later criticised for his defending on both of Croatia's goals during the match.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport3/worldcup2002/hi/matches_wallchart/italy_v_croatia/default.stm|title=Croatia punish Italy|publisher=BBC|date=8 June 2002|accessdate=14 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.repubblica.it/online/mondiali2002/itacrpag/itacrpag/itacrpag.html|title=Male Materazzi e Maldini, Non brilla Totti, bene Vieri|trans-title=Materazzi and Maldini bad, Totti does not shine, Vieri good|publisher=Reppublica.it|language=Italian|author=Massimo Vincenzi|date=8 June 2002|accessdate=14 December 2015}}</ref>
===UEFA Euro 2004=== Despite a long suspension with Inter,<ref name="Suspension"/> Materazzi was still called up by manager [[Giovanni Trapattoni]] for the [[UEFA Euro 2004]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.worldsoccer.com/news/trapattoni-names-italy-squad-for-euro-2004-55531|title=Trapattoni names Italy squad for EURO 2004|publisher=World Soccer|date=19 May 2004|accessdate=20 October 2018}}</ref> where he was on the bench for Italy's first two games but started in the final [[UEFA Euro 2004 Group C#Italy vs Bulgaria|group game]] against [[Bulgaria national football team|Bulgaria]] in place of the suspended [[Fabio Cannavaro]], as Italy came from behind to win 2–1; in the first half, Materazzi was judged to have allegedly fouled [[Dimitar Berbatov]] in the area, conceding a penalty, which [[Martin Petrov]] subsequently converted. Despite the win, Italy were eliminated in the first round on direct encounters, following a three-way five point tie with [[Denmark national football team|Denmark]] and [[Sweden national football team|Sweden]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/euro_2004/3787525.stm|title=Italy 2–1 Bulgaria|publisher=BBC|date=23 June 2004|accessdate=14 December 2015}}</ref>
Materazzi played his first match as captain for Italy on 17 November 2004 in a 1–0 friendly win over [[Finland national football team|Finland]] in which he also received a yellow card.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://eu-football.info/_match.php?id=2688|title=Football MATCH: 17.11.2004 Italy v Finland|publisher=EU-Football.info|accessdate=20 October 2018}}</ref> His second and final match as captain came in another friendly against [[Iceland national football team|Iceland]] on 30 March 2005 where he played in the first half.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://eu-football.info/_match.php?id=3097|title=Football MATCH: 30.03.2005 Italy v Iceland|publisher=EU-Football.info|accessdate=20 October 2018}}</ref>
===2006 World Cup=== [[File:Marco Materazzi.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Materazzi in 2006, during the FIFA World Cup in Germany]] Materazzi was included in the 23-man squad by manager [[Marcelo Lippi]] for the [[2006 FIFA World Cup]] which was his third major tournament.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rte.ie/sport/soccer/2006/0515/204699-italy/|title=Lippi names Italy 23 for Germany|publisher=rte.ie|date=14 June 2007|accessdate=20 October 2018}}</ref> He begun the tournament as a reserve player, but after [[Alessandro Nesta]] suffered an injury in the [[2006 FIFA World Cup - Group E#Czech Republic vs Italy|group match]] against the [[Czech Republic national football team|Czech Republic]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2006/jun/26/worldcup2006.sport9|title=Business as usual for Italy despite concern over Nesta|publisher=The Guardian|author=Russell Thomas|date=26 June 2006|accessdate=20 October 2018}}</ref> Materazzi came on as his replacement and made an impact by scoring a goal, and was named Man of the Match.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/world_cup_2006/4853358.stm|title=Czech Republic 0–2 Italy|publisher=BBC|date=22 June 2006|accessdate=14 December 2015}}</ref> He received a red card in the round of 16 match against [[Australia national association football team|Australia]] for a foul on [[Mark Bresciano]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.foxsports.com.au/football/italy-legend-marco-materazzi-discusses-2006-world-cup-in-exclusive-interview-for-fox-sports/news-story/4bd76b9c83f41df117058b4df05ccfc9?sv=f96affe74ac5765f10211b71df50184b|title=Italy legend Marco Materazzi discusses 2006 World Cup in exclusive interview for Fox Sports|publisher=Fox Sports|date=26 August 2012|accessdate=20 October 2018}}</ref> which ended in a 1–0 win to the Italians, and was suspended for the quarter-final against [[Ukraine national football team|Ukraine]], which Italy won 3–0.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/world_cup_2006/4991534.stm|title=Italy 1–0 Australia|publisher=BBC|date=26 June 2006|accessdate=14 December 2015}}</ref> In [[2006 FIFA World Cup Final|the final]] against [[France national football team|France]], Materazzi fouled [[Florent Malouda]] to concede a penalty, which [[Zinedine Zidane]] subsequently scored. He made another impact by scoring a goal to level the score, a header from a right sided corner by [[Andrea Pirlo]]. After the match went to extra-time, Materazzi and Zidane were involved in a confrontation in the 110th minute, where Materazzi verbally insulted Zinedine Zidane alongside tugging his shirt while Zidane attempted to walk away, which ended with [[2006 FIFA World Cup Final#Zidane sending off|Zidane head-butting]] Materazzi and receiving a red card.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2014/mar/11/world-cup-moments-zinedine-zidane-head-butt|title=World Cup stunning moments: Zinedine Zidane's head-butt|publisher=The Guardian|author=Ian McCourt|date=25 March 2018|accessdate=20 October 2018}}</ref> The game then continued to penalties. Materazzi scored Italy's second penalty as they defeated France 5–3 to claim their fourth FIFA World Cup.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/world_cup_2006/4991652.stm|title=Italy 1–1 France (aet)|publisher=BBC|author1=Jonathan Stevenson|date=9 July 2006|accessdate=14 December 2015}}</ref> After the final, the confrontation resulted in a major controversy as Zidane accused Materazzi of insulting his sister and mother. Additionally, Materazzi claimed that after he had grabbed Zidane's jersey, Zidane sarcastically said to him ''"If you want my shirt, I will give to you afterwards"''. Materazzi then revealed that he replied, ''"Preferisco la puttana di tua sorella<ref name=autogenerated1>[http://www.repubblica.it/2007/08/sezioni/sport/calcio/frase-materazzi/frase-materazzi/frase-materazzi.html Materazzi-Zidane, mistero svelato Ecco la frase che scatenò la testata – Calcio – Sport – Repubblica.it<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>"'' (''I would prefer your whore of a sister<ref name=autogenerated1 />''), which resulted in the head-butt.<ref> {{cite web|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story?id=378084&cc=5901|title=Materazzi reveals details of Zidane World Cup slur|publisher=[[Reuters]]|date=5 September 2006|accessdate=2 February 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090405025125/http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story?id=378084&cc=5901 |archivedate=5 April 2009 |df= }}</ref><ref name="World Cup">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2007/aug/18/newsstory.sport2|title=And Materazzi's exact words to Zidane were...|publisher=[[The Guardian]]|location=London|date=18 August 2007|accessdate=18 March 2008}}</ref> Three British [[tabloid newspaper]]s, the ''[[Daily Star (United Kingdom)|Daily Star]]'', the ''[[Daily Mail]]'' and ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]'', alleged that Materazzi had called Zidane ''"the son of a terrorist whore."'' Materazzi took legal action against all three newspapers and the allegations were later withdrawn.<ref>Tryhorn, Chris (2008-04-07). [https://www.theguardian.com/media/2008/apr/07/pressandpublishing.medialaw Zidane headbutt victim wins Star apology]. ''[[The Guardian]]''. Retrieved on 2009-02-09.</ref><ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/football/2009/feb/06/marco-materazzi-zinedine-zidane-the-sun-libel Materazzi wins British libel damages over Sun's claims about Zidane headbutt]. ''[[The Guardian]]'' (2009-02-06). Retrieved on 2009-02-09.</ref> FIFA later issued a [[Swiss franc|CHF]] 5,000 fine and a two-match ban against Materazzi. Alongside striker [[Luca Toni]], Materazzi was Italy's top scorer throughout the tournament with two goals; he also won 14 challenges throughout the competition.<ref name=simpatia>{{cite web|url=http://www.blitzquotidiano.it/sport/italia-2006-campioni-del-mondo-grosso-jolly-cannavaro-buffon-voto-simpatia-75-1883864/|title=Home Sport Italia 2006: campioni del mondo. Grosso jolly, Cannavaro e Buffon muro: voto simpatia 7,5|publisher=BlitzQuotidiano.it|language=Italian|author1=Antonio Sansonetti|date=6 June 2014|accessdate=3 July 2016}}</ref>
===UEFA Euro 2008=== Under Roberto Donadoni, Materazzi appeared consistently during the Euro 2008 qualifying campaign and became a starter after Alessandro Nesta's retirement.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idINIndia-28769420070801|title=Italy's Nesta retires from international game|publisher=Reuters.com|author=Mark Meadows|location=Milan|date=1 August 2007|accessdate=20 October 2018}}</ref> In the [[UEFA Euro 2008]] tournament,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2008/may/28/italy.euro2008.squad|title=Italy squad for Euro 2008|publisher=The Guardian|date=28 May 2008|accessdate=20 October 2018}}</ref> he started in the [[UEFA Euro 2008 Group C#Netherlands vs Italy|3–0 loss]] to the [[Netherlands national football team|Netherlands]] but was substituted in the 54th minute in what would later prove to be his final appearance for Italy, as he was replaced later in the tournament by [[Giorgio Chiellini]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2008/jun/09/euro2008.euro2008groupc2|title=Euro 2008: Holland v Italy – as it happened|publisher=The Guardian|author1=Paolo Bandini|date=10 June 2008|accessdate=14 December 2015}}</ref> Later, after Lippi's return, Materazzi was not called in the national team again.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.repubblica.it/2008/07/sezioni/sport/calcio/nazionale/lippi-presenta/prime-convocazioni/prime-convocazioni.html|title=Lippi richiama Gilardino e si tiene Del Piero|trans-title=Lippi recalls Gilardino and has Del Piero|publisher=Reppublica.it|author=Gianluca Moresco|location=Rome|date=16 August 2008|accessdate=20 October 2018}}</ref> He totaled 41 appearances and 2 goals for Italy.<ref name="EU-Football.info"/>
==Style of play== An aggressive, physical, and hard-tackling [[Defender (association football)#Centre-back|centre-back]], who was also known for his tight marking of opponents,<ref name="Materazzi"/> Materazzi was considered to be one of the best defenders of his generation, and was highly regarded by two of the world's most respected coaches, [[Marcello Lippi]] and [[José Mourinho]], later becoming close friends with both managers.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.futaa.com/football/article/why-i-cried-when-jose-left--materazzi |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-06-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140904083401/http://www.futaa.com/football/article/why-i-cried-when-jose-left--materazzi |archivedate=4 September 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Materazzi was lauded by his managers in particular for being a goal threat as a defender, due to his outstanding aerial ability, which made him dangerous during set pieces.<ref name="gazzetta"/> His prolific goalscoring allowed him to capture the record for most goals in a Serie A season by a defender, which was broken during the [[2000–01 Serie A|2000–01 season]].<ref name=gazzetta>{{cite web|title=I difensori e il vizio del gol Facchetti il top, poi Matrix|url=http://www.gazzetta.it/Calcio/26-10-2009/i-difensori-vizio-gol--601754131334.shtml|accessdate=14 September 2014|language=Italian|work=[[Gazzetta dello Sport]]}}</ref> He was also an accurate set piece and penalty kick taker, with a powerful shot from distance.<ref name="gazzetta"/> In addition to these attributes, he had solid technical skills and reliable distribution, and was known for frequently playing long balls to the strikers.<ref name="Materazzi"/> During his time with Internazionale, he developed the nickname ''Matrix''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.inter.it/aas/news/reader?N=43308&L=it|title=Foto: Marco Materazzi, Matrix|publisher=inter.it|date=26 December 2008|accessdate=19 August 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.calciogazzetta.it/altro/la-storia-di-un-campione-trattata-da-calcio-gazzetta/storie-di-calcio-marco-matrix-materazzi/|title=[Storie di Calcio] Marco “Matrix” Materazzi|trans-title=[Stories of Football] Marco “Matrix” Materazzi|publisher=calciogazzetta.it|language=Italian|date=21 June 2017|accessdate=20 October 2018}}</ref>
==Personal life== Marco Materazzi was born in [[Lecce]], where his father, [[Giuseppe Materazzi|Giuseppe]], a professional footballer, was playing for [[U.S. Lecce]].<ref name="Early life">{{cite web|url=https://thesefootballtimes.co/2018/09/10/the-violence-and-victory-of-marco-materazzi/|title=The violence and the victory of Marco Materazzi|publisher=These Football Times|author=Christopher Weir|date=10 September 2018|accessdate=14 October 2018}}</ref> Giuseppe was also a former football coach and manager of teams such as [[Pisa Calcio|Pisa]], [[S.S. Lazio|Lazio]], [[Sporting Clube de Portugal|Sporting CP]] and [[Tianjin Teda F.C.|Tianjin Teda]]. Materazzi's mother died when he was 15 years old.<ref name="Early life"/> His sister, Monia married Maurizio Maestrelli, the son of former manager [[Tommaso Maestrelli]]; he died on 28 November 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fcinter1908.it/in-evidenza/il-calcio-piange-maurizio-maestrelli/|title=Il calcio piange Maurizio Maestrelli|trans-title=The football mourns Maurizio Maestrelli|publisher=fcinter1908.it|language=Italian|author=Lorenzo Roca|date=29 November 2011|accessdate=19 October 2018}}</ref> His brother Matteo is a [[sports agent]].
As stated by his father, Marco grew up a supporter of Lazio.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tifonet.it/notizie/materazzi-e-i-tifosi-laziali-amore-finito-22311|title=Materazzi e i tifosi laziali: amore finito?|trans-title=Materazzi and Lazio fans: finished love?|publisher=tifo-net.it|language=Italian|date=14 May 2007|accessdate=19 October 2018}}</ref> In September 2007, he released his autobiography called "Una vita da guerriero" (A life as a warrior) published by journalists Andrea Elefante (from [[La Gazzetta dello Sport|Gazzetta dello Sport]]) and Roberto De Ponti (from [[Corriere della Sera]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gazzetta.it/Calcio/SerieA/Squadre/Inter/Primo_Piano/2007/08_Agosto/31/Libromatbis.shtml|title=Materazzi si racconta in un libro|trans-title=Materazzi told in a book|publisher=La Gazetta dello Sport|language=Italian|date=8 August 2007|accessdate=19 October 2018}}</ref>
Materazzi was married on 23 June 1997 with Daniela, whom he has three children: Anna, Davide and Gianmarco.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.golssip.it/wags/calciatori-in-famiglia/marco-materazzi-un-anniversario-davvero-speciale-21-anni-di-matrimonio/|title=Marco Materazzi, un anniversario davvero speciale: “21 anni di matrimonio”|trans-title=Marco Materazzi, a really special anniversary: "21 years of marrige"|publisher=Golssip.it|language=Italian|date=23 June 2018|accessdate=18 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.inter.it/it/news/30777/materazzi-a-raggi-x-io-e-i-miei-figli|title=Materazzi a 'Raggi X': "Io e i miei figli"|trans-title=Materazzi to Raggi X: Me and my children|publisher=inter.it|language=Italian|date=28 December 2005|accessdate=19 October 2018}}</ref>

{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox astronaut |name = Miss Baker |other_names = |image = Miss Baker, the squirrel monkey.jpg |image_size = |caption = |type = Space pioneer |status = |birth_date = {{birth year|1957}} |birth_place = [[Iquitos]], Peru<ref name="findGrave"/> |death_date = {{death date|1984|11|29|}} (aged 27) |death_place = [[Auburn University]] clinic, [[Auburn, Alabama|Auburn]], [[Alabama]] |occupation = |current_occupation = |previous_occupation = |alma_mater = |rank = |time = 16 minutes |selection = |eva1 = |eva2 = |mission = [[PGM-19 Jupiter#Biological flights|Jupiter AM-18]] |insignia = |Date of ret = |awards = }} '''Miss Baker''' (1957 – November 29, 1984) was a [[squirrel monkey]] who in 1959 became, along with [[rhesus macaque]] Miss Able, one of the first two animals launched into space by the United States and safely returned.<ref name="findGrave">{{cite web|url=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/10621868|publisher=[[Find a Grave]]|title=Miss Baker|accessdate=September 14, 2011}}</ref>
==Previous animal flights==
Previous United States efforts at [[monkeys in space|launching monkeys to space]] had met with the animals' demise from suffocation or parachute failure, and [[Soviet Union]] efforts had fared little better, to the chagrin of [[animal rights activists]].<ref name="v2">{{cite web|url=http://www.astronautix.com/lvs/v2.htm|title=V2|publisher=Astronautix|accessdate=September 14, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080906120723/http://www.astronautix.com/lvs/v2.htm|archivedate=September 6, 2008|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="bbc"/> The Soviet Union had recovered two dogs, the first mammals to be recovered from suborbital space flight, from an altitude of {{convert|101|km|ft|sp=us}} on July 22, 1951 and subsequently recovered more dogs.<ref>{{cite book|title=Challenge to Apollo: The Soviet Union and the Space Race, 1945–1974|author=Asif. A. Siddiqi|year=2000|publisher=NASA|page=95|url=https://history.nasa.gov/SP-4408pt1.pdf}}</ref> The United States had flown monkeys and mice by [[Aerobee (rocket)|Aerobee rocket]] to heights below the [[Kármán line|edge of space]] beginning in 1951.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://history.nasa.gov/printFriendly/animals.html | title=Animals in Space | publisher=NASA | accessdate=October 9, 2011}}</ref>
== Pre-flight == The squirrel monkey who was to become known as Miss Baker was purchased along with 25 other squirrel monkeys at a pet shop in Miami, Florida, and brought to the Naval Aviation Medical School in [[Pensacola, Florida|Pensacola]]. Fourteen of the candidates tolerated confinement for periods up to 24 hours, electrodes all over their bodies, and monitoring at all hours. Miss Baker "stood out from the rest because of her intelligence and loving, docile manner", relayed Colin Burgess and Chris Dubbs in their 2007 book ‘Animals In Space: From Research Rockets to the Space Shuttle.’ For this, and her apparent pleasure at being handled with tender loving care, she earned the nickname TLC.<ref name="Burgess"/>
With experiments imminent, the Army named their monkey "Alpha," and the Navy followed with "Bravo," names taken directly from the [[NATO phonetic alphabet|phonetic alphabet]]. Before flight, though, the names changed to the first letters of the antiquated [[Joint Army/Navy Phonetic Alphabet]].<ref name="Burgess"/>
== The flight == [[File:Miss Baker in her bio-pack.jpg|thumb|Miss Baker awaits launch.]] [[File:Jupiter AM-18 pre-launch.jpg|thumb|Jupiter AM-18 stands ready for its 2:39 am launch at [[Cape Canaveral]] launch complex 26B.]]
Miss Baker wore a helmet lined with rubber and chamois leather plus a jacket for launch, in addition to a respiration meter affixed to her nose with model cement, and she was fitted into a snug capsule of shoebox size, 9¾ × 12½ × 6¾ inches (24.8 × 31.8 × 17.1 cm) insulated with rubber and fiberglass. Life support was an oxygen bottle with a pressure valve, and [[lithium hydroxide]] to absorb exhaled [[carbon dioxide]] and moisture.<ref name="Burgess"/>
On May 28, 1959, at 2:39 am, a [[Jupiter-C|Jupiter rocket]] lifted Miss Baker and Miss Able to an altitude of {{convert|300|mi|km}} through an acceleration of 38 [[standard gravity|gs]] for a 16-minute flight which also included 9 minutes of weightlessness.<ref name="findGrave"/><ref name="bbc">{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/may/28/newsid_3725000/3725961.stm|title=1959: Monkeys survive space mission|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=September 14, 2011}}</ref><ref name="Beischer1962">{{cite journal |author1=Beischer, DE |author2=Fregly, AR |title=Animals and man in space. A chronology and annotated bibliography through the year 1960. |journal=US Naval School of Aviation Medicine |volume=ONR TR ACR-64 |issue=AD0272581 |year=1962 |url=http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/9288 |accessdate=June 14, 2011}}</ref><ref name="npr">{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=104578202|title=After 50 Years, Space Monkeys Not Forgotten|author=Greenfieldboyce, Neil|date=May 28, 2009|accessdate=September 14, 2011}}</ref> The flight traveled {{convert|1500|mi|km}} downrange from the pad at [[Cape Canaveral]] launch complex 26B to the Atlantic Ocean near [[Puerto Rico]] where the capsule was recovered by [[USS Kiowa (AT-72)|USS ''Kiowa'']].<ref name="Jupiter">{{cite web|url=http://www.astronautix.com/lvs/jupiter.htm|title=Jupiter|accessdate=September 15, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111010114842/http://astronautix.com/lvs/jupiter.htm|archivedate=October 10, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="recoveryPic">{{cite web|url=http://www.nafts.net/images/Ships%20pics/ATF/Kiowa/Kiowa513z1.jpg|title=Figure 8|accessdate=September 14, 2011}}</ref>
The following table shows some characteristics of the monkeys on Jupiter AM-18 and the measurements taken during flight. Some of Able's measurements had data problems as indicated.
{| class="wikitable collapsible" border="1" |+ Experiment overview<ref name="bbc"/><ref name="Burgess"/><ref name="Beischer1962"/> |- ! scope="col" | Measurement ! scope="col" | Experiment 2A – Baker ! scope="col" | Experiment 2B – Able |- | species || [[squirrel monkey]] || [[rhesus monkey]] |- | weight || {{convert|1|lb|kg}} || {{convert|7|lb|kg}} |- | flight prep time || 8 hours || 3 days |- | [[electrocardiogram]] || {{yes}} || {{yes-no|problems}} |- | [[electromyogram]], extensor || {{no}} || {{yes}} |- | electromyogram, flexor || {{no}} || {{yes}} |- | heart sounds || {{no}} || {{yes}} |- | pulse velocity, femoral vs carotid || {{no}} || {{yes-no|problems}} |- | respiratory rate || {{yes}} || {{yes}} |- | body temperature || {{yes}} || {{yes}} |- | ambient temperature || {{yes}} || {{yes}} |- | ambient capsule pressure || {{yes}} || {{yes}} |- | relative humidity || {{no}} || {{yes-no|problems}} |- | percent carbon dioxide || {{no}} || {{yes}} |- | monitor electric shock || {{no}} || {{yes-no|problems}} |- | monitor lever response || {{no}} || {{yes-no|problems}} |- | monitor light stimulus || {{no}} || {{yes}} |- | monitor camera || {{no}} || {{yes}} |- |[[nuclear emulsion|emulsion plates]] for heavy nuclei of cosmic origin || {{yes}} || {{yes}} |}
Able and Baker were not alone on the flight. They were accompanied by ''[[Neurospora]]''; samples of human blood; ''[[Escherichia coli|E. coli]]''; onions; [[mustard (condiment)|mustard]] and [[maize|corn]] seeds; ''[[Drosophila]]'' pupae; [[yeast]]; and [[sea urchin]] eggs and sperm.<ref name="Beischer1962"/>
Able died four days after the flight from a highly unusual cardiac fibrillation in reaction to anesthesia to remove electrodes. "This is the type of anesthetic death every surgeon fears," said Colonel Robert Hullinghorst, deputy at Ft. Knox where the surgery took place, "We don't know exactly why it occurs." An autopsy found no problems that may have contributed to her death.<ref name="Burgess"/> Able is stuffed and on display at the [[National Air and Space Museum]].<ref name="50yrs">{{cite web|title=NASA marks 50th anniversary of monkeys Able and Miss Baker in space|url=http://blog.al.com/space-news/2009/05/nasa_marks_50th_anniversary_of.html|date=May 28, 2009|accessdate=September 14, 2011|publisher=The Huntsville Times}}</ref><ref name="77party">{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=bQgdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=_Z0EAAAAIBAJ&dq=big%20george%20miss%20baker%20pensacola&pg=5885%2C6514718|title=Space Monkey Marks Birthday|work=Tuscaloosa News|date=June 30, 1977|accessdate=September 14, 2011}}</ref>
== Post-flight == [[File:Miss Baker with Certificate of Merit.jpg|thumb|The [[American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals|ASPCA]] awarded Miss Baker with a Certificate of Merit for Distinguished Service, supporting "'carefully controlled scientific' use of animals as space pathfinders for the 'mutual benefit of man and animals.'"<ref name="cert">{{cite news|title=Monkey Baker is Honored by ASPCA|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=rlEqAAAAIBAJ&sjid=YFEEAAAAIBAJ&dq=baker%20certificate%20of%20merit&pg=6984%2C6934026|work=The ([[Lexington, North Carolina]]) Dispatch|date=June 30, 1959|accessdate=September 15, 2011}}</ref>]] [[File:Birthday party for Miss Baker.jpg|thumb|Miss Baker's birthdays were marked by balloons and some of her favorite foods.]]
Owing to their successful return from space to the USS Kiowa (ATF-72) and their crew, Able and Baker appeared on the cover of [[Life (magazine)|''Life'' magazine]], June 15, 1959.<ref name="findGrave"/>
In 1962, [[Pensacola, Florida|Pensacola]] caretakers held a marriage ceremony to wed Miss Baker to Big George.<ref name="Windham">{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hozNwPLWFEIC&lpg=PA141&dq=miss%20baker%20big%20george%20pensacola%20wedding&pg=PA141#v=onepage&q=miss%20baker%20big%20george%20pensacola%20wedding&f=false | title=Alabama, One Big Front Porch | publisher=NewSouth Books | author=Windham, Kathryn Tucker | year=2007 | pages=168| isbn=9781588382191 }}</ref>
Miss Baker lived at the Naval Aerospace Medical Center in Pensacola, Florida until 1971.<ref name="25Tuscaloosa">{{cite news|title=Little Miss Baker Back in Spotlight|work=Tuscaloosa News|date=May 28, 1982|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=3iQdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=S6UEAAAAIBAJ&dq=miss%20baker%20monkey&pg=6678%2C6793325|accessdate=September 14, 2011}}</ref>
In 1971, Miss Baker moved to the [[U.S. Space & Rocket Center]] in [[Huntsville, Alabama]], where she entertained museum visitors and drew 100–150 letters a day from schoolchildren.<ref name="npr"/><ref name="USSRC20">{{cite book |title=20th Anniversary U.S. Space and Rocket Center |date=March 17, 1990 |publisher=USSRC}}</ref> The 1977 birthday celebrations brought balloons, camera flashes, and the regular fare of cottage cheese for Miss Baker and Big George.<ref name="77party"/>
Big George predeceased Miss Baker on January 8, 1979, and three months later, Norman, from the [[Yerkes National Primate Research Center]], became her second mate in a ceremony presided over by Alabama District Court judge Dan McCoy. Miss Baker refused to wear her white wedding train for the event, tearing it off after a few seconds.<ref name="Burgess">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/?id=xSdHVIpsrKkC&lpg=PA141&dq=miss%20baker%20monkey%20norman&pg=PA141#v=onepage&q=miss%20baker%20monkey%20norman&f=false |title=Animals in Space: From Research Rockets to the Space Shuttle |author=Burgess, Colin |pages=134–141|isbn=9780387496788 |date=2007-07-05 }}</ref><ref name="WedNorm">{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=wAUvAAAAIBAJ&sjid=9jIDAAAAIBAJ&dq=miss%20baker%20monkey%20norman%20died&pg=6633%2C1780576 |title=Monkeys Wed at Huntsville |date=April 11, 1979 |work=Rome (Georgia, U.S.) News-Tribune |accessdate=September 14, 2011}}</ref>
In 1982, center director Ed Buckbee said, "Baker delights visitors every day with her energy and antics with her husband Norman."<ref name="25Tuscaloosa"/> Her birthday was celebrated within a few weeks of the actual day, on the anniversary of her flight, May 28 each year.<ref name="25Tuscaloosa"/>
In celebration of the 25th anniversary of her spaceflight, Baker was treated to a [[rubber duck]] and, her favorite, strawberry [[gelatin]] with bananas, along with well-wishes from thousands of people.<ref name="25Tuscaloosa"/><ref name="silver">{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=iZUpAAAAIBAJ&sjid=tccEAAAAIBAJ&dq=miss%20baker%20monkey&pg=1422%2C7469094 |work=(Florence/Sheffield/Tuscumbia/Muscle Shoals) Times Daily|title=Miss Baker A-OK|date=May 29, 1984|accessdate=September 14, 2011}}</ref>
[[File:Miss Baker's Gravestone bw.JPG|thumb|Miss Baker's gravestone frequently has one or more bananas on top.]] In 1984, Miss Baker died of kidney failure at a clinic at [[Auburn University]] after attaining the record for oldest living squirrel monkey.<ref name="findGrave"/><ref name="TDObit">{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=cWgeAAAAIBAJ&sjid=78cEAAAAIBAJ&dq=miss%20baker%20monkey&pg=4330%2C142872 |title=Memorial Set for Miss Baker |work=(Florence/Sheffield/Tuscumbia/Muscle Shoals) Times Daily |date=December 2, 1984 |accessdate=September 14, 2011}}</ref> She is buried on the grounds at the [[U.S. Space & Rocket Center]]. Her tombstone routinely has one or more bananas on top.<ref name="npr"/>
==References== {{Commons category}} {{Reflist|2}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Baker, Miss}} [[Category:U.S. Space & Rocket Center]] [[Category:Animals in space]] [[Category:Individual monkeys]] [[Category:1957 animal births]] [[Category:1984 animal deaths]] [[Category:Deaths from kidney failure]] [[Category:Famous animals of Huntsville, Alabama]]

{{More citations needed|article about a ranching sim video game|date=February 2014}} {{Infobox video game |title = Monster Rancher 4 |image = monsterrancher4.jpg |image_size = 200px |developer = [[Tecmo]] |publisher = [[Tecmo Koei|Tecmo]] |designer = |series = ''[[Monster Rancher]]'' |released = {{vgrelease|JP|August 14, 2003|NA|November 13, 2003}} |genre = [[Life simulation game]] |modes = [[Single player]], or [[Multiplayer game|two players versus]] |platforms = [[PlayStation 2]] }} '''''Monster Rancher 4''''' (known in Japan as {{nihongo|'''''Monster Farm 4'''''|モンスターファーム4|Monsutā Fāmu Fō}}) is a [[Pet-raising simulation|monster breeding and management game]] that was released by [[Tecmo]] for the [[PlayStation 2]] in 2003.
==Gameplay==
Like the previous installments, this game involves the raising, breeding, and fighting of monsters. Monsters are created via a "Saucer Stone" regeneration system. Players must go to a Shrine, where they swap the Monster Rancher 4 disc with a CD, DVD, or another game disc. A monster is then generated from the data contained on that disc. Once a player regenerates a monster, they can raise it on a ranch, and train it to compete in battles. The limit for monsters depend on the size of their ranch but the maximum is 5 monsters.
==Plotline== The user's character (default: Phayne) stows away on a ship after being kicked out of the Elives School. He then meets a once famous FIMBA breeder, TeeTee. He is later offered a job running his own ranch. The original trainer assistant, Yuri, catches up with Phayne. When the Official Cup E is won, Yuri quits, and Cesare's (the shrine priest) daughter, Rio, becomes the trainer assistant. Rio is also revealed to be able to talk to monsters (reason explained later) and that is why she is shy and hated. The main character will begin using training gadgets, which run off geonyte (an energy found in spirit trees). The trainer's first monster will grow lonely. Eventually, three monsters will be permitted on the ranch. Rio will discover a cave (the Togle Caves) and Phayne will travel down it. On the first trip, he will discoveer a Life Tablet (a tablet which allows for a blueprint for a life training gadget). On the second trip, he and Rio will discover a saucer stone fragment, a Gaia Stone. Rio touches it and sees a terrifying image. When the breeder returns home, Pollocck informs them that there is a geonyte shortage. Phayne will travel into the cave once more, and at the end, they will find King Shiden, a raiden, who is the cause of the shortage. After defeating him, raidens will be unlocked, and breeder rank D will be achieved.
After winning the Official Cup D, Phayne is given a boat. The boat allows him to travel to other places. He will travel to Ryuwn, the capital, and will apply for Ryuwn registration. This is unavailable. Phayne reunites with old school friends, Gram and Phylia, and meets her ailing grandma, Mauro. Phayne is sent on a mission to find healing mushrooms in the Togle Caves. After defeating Blobster, he receives the mushrooms. He returns them, and is then sent on a mission by Karnab (President of FIMBA) to find "junk." You then find another Gaia Stone Fragment, and Rio sees another terrifying vision. After going back, he faces a Mogi, and receives the "junk." He is then granted access to FIMBA battles, and is given a Breeder Rank C.
After winning the Official Grade C, Phayne hears news of missing explorers in the Kalaragi Jungle, and travels to rescue them. You then face Don Mudlone, a Gaboo (reference to MR2), and, after defeating him, find out about monster "alterations." Karnab asks you to come to FIMBA for a surprise (rank B) and you are told to go to Torble to find out about the alterations. You go to Torble to meet another school friend, Wit. He takes you to the University, where TeeTee is revealed to be his assistant. The next week, in Torble, you are granted access to the Torble (IMA) battles. You meet another friend, Deihl, and find him to be cruel to his monsters. Rio punches him in the face. Phayne declares that he will defeat him. You then revisit Wit. He gives you a magic training medal, a medal that enhances the effects of training. You win the Ofiicial Grade B, and decide to go to Vizley to get a teacher to speak to Deihl.
You go to Vizley and it is revealed why Phayne was expelled, but Mrs. Casa, Phayne's old teacher, refuses to speak to Deihl. You are granted Breeder Rank A for beating Deihl. You go to The Official Rank A defeat Wit. The trophy is made from a third Gaia Stone, and Rio once again sees a clearer, more terrifying vision. After a series of events, Phayne travels to the Promiass Ruins. On the first two trips, you see two inscriptions about a "Dark Age" from long ago. On a third trip, you face an all-knowing monster who knows why Rio can talk to monsters and what the vision means. After defeating him, the main character discovers that Rio was sealed in a saucer stone in the Dark Age, and that she led the battle against the "Dark Lord," Xevion. The vision was of the Dark Age. Upon returning home, Cesare confronts Rio, and the two reach an understanding, and Rio accepts him as her father, though that is biologically incorrect. Phayne is granted S Rank, and discovers that the Tome of Black Arts, a book containing arts for monster strengthening, was stolen from the school library. After a chain of events, Phayne goes to the Kawrea Volcano. Rio finds the final piece of the Gaia Stone, and finally remembers herself from long ago. On their final journey, Rio, Phayne, and Teetee discover what happened that got Phayne expelled. In the heart of the volcano, Rio, Phayne, Wit, Teetee, and the monsters team up to beat Xevion. He blocks the exit. The four Gaia Stones join together and revive a Phoenix from long ago, Suzaku. She flies them out, and gives them a Fire Feather, which is used to revive a Phoenix. Elongated Passageways are opened in the adventure places, thus ending the storyline.
==Monsters== Some breeds are new to this game. There are 34 main types of monsters, but two different monsters can be combined together to create subspecies, thus making 328 different species available.
==Raising Monsters== Players can house up to 5 monsters on their ranch at a time, thus allowing monster-to-monster friendships, tag-team, and group battles. Monsters that have been raised together for a long time will have a high affinity level, which describes how well the monsters get along with each other. Having high affinity is important for effective teamwork in battles.
===Training=== This game implements the use of training gadgets, which allow the player to customize their monsters' stats. The player can acquire these gadgets as they progress through the game. They come in many different varieties and training levels. The higher level of training they are, the more space they will take up on the ranch, so the player has to choose wisely on which gadgets to use.
===Proper Care=== In addition to training their monster for battle, the player also has to raise it properly and make sure it has a balanced diet. The player must not be too strict with their monster, or it may become stressed and try to run away. They must also try not to spoil their monster too much, or it may become spoiled and not take its training or battling seriously. To avoid being too strict or too lenient with the monster, scold it and praise it according to how well, or how badly it did on its training, and make sure to feed it a balanced diet of foods, instead of only feeding it what it likes, or only feeding it a certain type of food.
===Retirement=== After the monsters reach a certain age, they can not be raised any further, and they cannot participate in any more battles. To avoid having all of the monsters retired at the same time, it is best to raise monsters of different ages.
==Monster Battles== After raising training, and feeding their monsters, the player may compete them in competitions. Players compete in competitions to increase their battle rank, and to earn money and fame. Once the player has increased their rank, they may compete in higher-ranked competitions. Winning competitions is important if the player wants to become a highly acclaimed breeder.
===Battle System=== The monsters fight using skills that they have acquired through training. They can use their skills with Guts, indicated by a meter on the battle screen. If there aren't enough Guts to use a certain skill, then the player has to wait until the Guts meter builds up again as the battle goes on. The battle will last until the life of one of the monsters is depleted, or until time runs out.
===Counter-attacking=== One of the features of the battle system is using counter-attacks, which can substantially affect the outcome of battle. To use a counter-attack, hold down the L2 button and press a skill button. The skill button chosen must be the same skill that the opponent uses. If executed properly and with perfect timing, then the monster will successfully counter the opponent's attack, both saving itself from damage, and inflicting damage on its opponent.
==Adventure Mode== One of the features of Monster Rancher 4 is exploring different lands for rare items and to discover special monster breeds. The player's team of monsters accompanies them on these journeys, battling stray monsters and the "Boss" monster of each area. These battles can help raise the monsters' experience. At the beginning of the game, the player can only visit a limited number of areas, but as they progress through the game, they will be able to visit more advanced and dangerous areas. Some areas have special rare monster breeds that cannot be found anywhere else, and once the player finds these rare monsters, they will be able to regenerate them and raise them on their ranch. The four different lands you can eventually explore are the togle caves, the kalaragi jungle, the promiass ruins, and the volcano.
* '''Togle Cave''' - Unlock At Rank D (Monster Rank E) * '''Kalaragi Jungle''' - Unlock At Rank C (Monster Rank D(1F-5F) Rank C(6F,7F) * '''Promiass Ruins''' - Unlock At Rank S (Monster Rank B(1F-XF) Rank A(YF-8F)) * '''Kawrea Volcano''' - Unlock At Rank S (After Defeat Turtle at Promiass Ruins 8F)(Monster Rank A)
After Complete the games through. Load game and wait until pass 2 weeks. Dr.Karnab will tell you that he discover the secret way from all Adventure mode. After that, you can go to adventure and meet '''Rank S Monster''' by right click (+ Mode)
==Reception== {{Video game reviews | MC = 77/100<ref name=MC>{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/playstation-2/monster-rancher-4 |title=Monster Rancher 4 for PlayStation 2 Reviews |publisher=[[Metacritic]] |accessdate=June 8, 2016}}</ref> | Edge = 4/10<ref>{{cite journal |author=Edge staff |title=Monster Rancher 4 |magazine=[[Edge (magazine)|Edge]] |issue=132 |date=January 2004 |page=106}}</ref> | EGM = 6.33/10<ref>{{cite journal |author=EGM staff |title=Monster Rancher 4 |magazine=[[Electronic Gaming Monthly]] |issue=174 |date=January 2004 |page=142}}</ref> | GI = 8.25/10<ref>{{cite journal |last=Reiner |first=Andrew |url=http://www.gameinformer.com/NR/exeres/3657D96B-03DE-4313-A819-8368B6DDC23C.htm |title=Monster Rancher Action Adventure 4 [sic] |magazine=[[Game Informer]] |issue=128 |date=December 2003 |page=145 {{Use mdy dates|date=January 2015}} {{Infobox professional wrestler | image = Nancybenoit.jpg | alt = | caption = | names = Devil Angel
Fallen Angel
