Robin Green
Woman | height = | weight = | birth_name = Nancy Elizabeth Toffoloni | spouse = {{marriage|Jim Daus|1982|1985|end=div}}
{{Marriage|[[Kevin Sullivan (wrestler)|Kevin Sullivan]]|1985|1997|end=div}}
{{Marriage|[[Chris Benoit]]|2000|2007|end=D.}} | children = 1 | birth_date = {{Birth date|1964|5|17}} | birth_place = [[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]], U.S. | death_date = {{Death date and age|2007|6|22|1964|5|21}} | death_place = [[Fayetteville, Georgia]], U.S. | death_cause = [[Asphyxia]] by strangulation | billed = | trainer = | debut = July 7, 1984 | retired = May 26, 1997 }} '''Nancy Elizabeth Benoit''' (née '''Toffoloni''', formerly '''Daus''' and '''Sullivan'''; May 17, 1964 – June 22, 2007) was an American [[professional wrestling]] [[Manager (professional wrestling)|valet]] and [[model (person)|model]]. She was best known for her appearances with [[Extreme Championship Wrestling]] and [[World Championship Wrestling]] in the mid-1990s under the [[ring name]] '''Woman'''.{{cite web|url=http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Wrestling/2007/06/25/4290333.html|title=Looking back on the career of "Woman"|author=Chris Schramm|publisher=[[Québecor Média]]|work=[[Canoe.ca]]|accessdate=January 17, 2015|date=June 25, 2007}} On June 22–23, 2007, she and then her son Daniel were [[Chris Benoit double-murder and suicide|murdered by her husband]], wrestler [[Chris Benoit]], who committed suicide on June 24, 2007. ==Early life== After graduating [[DeLand High School]], Nancy got a job answering phones at [[State Farm Insurance]].{{cite web|author=Cal Massey and Jeff Wilen|url= http://www.news-journalonline.com/NewsJournalOnline/News/Local/newWEST01062707.htm|title=Slain wife of wrestler a Deland High School graduate|publisher=Daytona Beach News Journal Online|accessdate=June 27, 2007|date=June 27, 2007 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070630001752/http://www.news-journalonline.com/NewsJournalOnline/News/Local/newWEST01062707.htm |archivedate = June 30, 2007}} When [[George Napolitano]] needed a beautiful young girl for the cover of the June 1984 edition of the pro-wrestling magazine ''Wrestling All Stars'', fellow photographer Bill Otten suggested the 20-year-old Nancy Toffoloni Daus for the role. Nancy, who had worked as a model, often sat alongside her then-husband Jim. She had also been selling programs at the Orlando shows and appeared as Para in the old "Apartment Wrestling" features. It was on this shoot where she met [[Kevin Sullivan (wrestler)|Kevin Sullivan]], who eventually wanted her to be a part of his wrestling entourage. After months of convincing, Nancy finally became an on-air valet, taking the ring name "Fallen Angel". ==Professional wrestling career== ===Early career (1984–1989)=== She made her in-ring debut on June 30, 1984 in Miami, Florida for [[Championship Wrestling from Florida|Florida Championship Wrestling]]. She became a part of Kevin Sullivan's [[List of professional wrestling terms#S|stable]] of [[kayfabe]] "Satanists", which also included wrestlers [[Winona Littleheart|The Lock]], [[Luna Vachon]], [[Mark Lewin|The Purple Haze]], and [[Oliver Humperdink|Sir Oliver Humperdink]]. Nancy and Kevin Sullivan traveled throughout the United States using the "Satanist" gimmick for promotions such as Angelo Savoldi's ICW and [[Southwest Championship Wrestling]]. The two married in 1985. ===World Championship Wrestling (1989–1990)=== She first appeared in WCW as a "fan" of [[Rick Steiner]] named Robin Green, wearing a Steiner T-shirt and large glasses. She would sit in the audience and would interact with Steiner whenever he appeared. She eventually turned on him, aligning herself with Kevin Sullivan and adopting the name Woman and became the manager of Doom ([[Butch Reed]] and [[Ron Simmons]]). After leaving Doom, she aligned herself with [[Ric Flair]] and the [[Four Horsemen (professional wrestling)|Four Horsemen]]. ===Extreme Championship Wrestling (1993–1996)=== In late 1993, Sullivan and Nancy joined the [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]]-based promotion [[Extreme Championship Wrestling]], where Nancy reverted to the ring name "Woman". In December 1993, Sullivan and [[Tazz|The Tazmaniac]] won the [[ECW World Tag Team Championship|ECW Tag Team Championship]]. They held the championship until March 1994, when they were defeated by [[The Public Enemy (professional wrestling)|The Public Enemy]]. After Sullivan left ECW in spring 1994, Woman began managing [[The Sandman (wrestler)|The Sandman]]. The Sandman's character was estranged from his wife and valet, [[Lori Fullington|Peaches]], who had left him after The Sandman accidentally struck her during a match while temporarily blinded. Woman drove a wedge between The Sandman and Peaches, convincing him that Peaches was cheating on him with [[Tommy Cairo]]. In keeping with The Sandman's character, Woman would open his beers and light his cigarettes prior to matches. She began carrying a [[Shinai|Singapore cane]] with which she would strike The Sandman's opponents.{{cite book|author=Thom Loverro|title=The Rise & Fall of ECW: Extreme Championship Wrestling|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=j0dlOLyCj6YC&pg=PA60|date=22 May 2007|publisher=Simon and Schuster|isbn=978-1-4165-6156-9|pages=60–}}{{cite book|author1=Steven Johnson|author2=Heath McCoy|author3=Irv Muchnick|title=Benoit: Wrestling with the Horror That Destroyed a Family and Crippled a Sport|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=e0rLnIRWqjUC&pg=PT48|date=1 November 2007|publisher=ECW Press|isbn=978-1-55490-315-3|pages=48–}} At ''When Worlds Collide'' on May 14, 1994, Woman and The Sandman lost to Cairo and Peaches in a [[Professional wrestling match types#Kendo Stick match|Singapore Cane match]], after which Peaches caned The Sandman in the groin until Woman threw salt in her eyes, enabling The Sandman to regroup and cane Cairo and Peaches.{{cite book|author=Scott E. Williams|title=Hardcore History: The Extremely Unauthorized Story of ECW|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4EQtAgAAQBAJ&pg=PT52|date=13 December 2013|publisher=Skyhorse Publishing Company, Incorporated|isbn=978-1-61321-582-1|pages=52–}} In mid-1994, The Sandman began feuding with [[Tommy Dreamer]] after he kissed Woman. The feud culminated in an [["I Quit" match]] on October 1, 1994, during which The Sandman was seemingly blinded when Dreamer pushed a lit cigarette into his eye and then caned him in the face. Following the bout, Woman announced that she was leaving The Sandman as he was now "useless". After Tommy Cairo mocked The Sandman, a guilt-stricken Dreamer challenged him to a match at [[November to Remember#1994|November to Remember]] on November 5, 1994. At the same event, Peaches attempted to reconcile with The Sandman. Woman interrupted the reconciliation, caning Peaches and threatening The Sandman. After Dreamer came to the ring to stop Woman, The Sandman revealed that he was not in fact blinded and attacked Dreamer, with his estrangement from Woman a ploy to pit Dreamer and Cairo against one another.{{cite book|author=Thom Loverro|title=The Rise & Fall of ECW: Extreme Championship Wrestling|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JrGwTebNiUIC&pg=PA66|date=22 May 2007|publisher=Simon and Schuster|isbn=978-1-4165-6156-9|pages=66–}} In April 1995, Woman again left The Sandman, aligning herself with [[Shane Douglas]]. At [[Hostile City Showdown#1995|Hostile City Showdown]] on April 15, 1995, she helped The Sandman defeat Douglas for his [[List of ECW World Heavyweight Champions|second]] [[ECW World Heavyweight Championship]] by striking him in the knee with a Singapore cane, revealing the turn to have been another ruse. Following The Sandman's victory, Woman began carrying the ECW World Heavyweight Championship to ringside. Throughout mid-1995, she helped The Sandman defend his championship in a series of bouts with [[Mick Foley|Cactus Jack]]. In September 1995, she began also managing The Sandman's ally, [[ECW World Television Championship|ECW World Television Champion]] [[2 Cold Scorpio]]. In late 1995, The Sandman began feuding with [[Mikey Whipwreck]], during which a controversial [[glossary of professional wrestling terms#Angle|storyline]] began in which Woman became visibly [[sexual arousal|aroused]] while watching The Sandman cane Whipwreck.{{cite book|author=Scott E. Williams|title=Hardcore History: The Extremely Unauthorized Story of ECW|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4EQtAgAAQBAJ&pg=PT89|date=13 December 2013|publisher=Skyhorse Publishing Company, Incorporated|isbn=978-1-61321-582-1|pages=89–}} The Sandman's reign lasted until October 28, 1995, when he lost to Whipwreck in a [[ladder match]] after [[Stone Cold Steve Austin|Stunning Steve Austin]] prevented Woman from interfering. On October 28, 1995, 2 Cold Scorpio defeated [[Rocco Rock]] in a singles bout to win the [[ECW World Tag Team Championship]], then selected The Sandman as his partner. The Sandman regained the ECW World Heavyweight Championship in a [[Professional wrestling match types#Basic elimination matches|three-way dance]] with Whipwreck and Austin at [[December to Dismember (1995)|December to Dismember]] on December 9, 1995, giving Woman control of all three championships. On December 29, 1995 at [[Holiday Hell#1995|Holiday Hell]], Mikey Whipwreck defeated 2 Cold Scorpio in a singles match with the ECW World Tag Team Championship on the line. The Sandman's third reign as ECW World Heavyweight Champion lasted until January 27, 1996, when he lost to [[Raven (wrestler)|Raven]]. On the January 27, 1996 episode of ''[[ECW Hardcore TV]]'', Woman announced that she was returning to World Championship Wrestling, parting ways with The Sandman and 2 Cold Scorpio. ===World Championship Wrestling (1996–1997)=== Woman made her return to WCW on the January 22, 1996 episode of ''[[WCW Monday Nitro]]'' as one of many women who stood in the aisle and waved as [[Hulk Hogan]] and [[Randy Savage]] came to the ring. On the February 5 episode of ''Nitro'' she turned on Savage during his match with [[Chris Benoit]] and rejoined Flair, [[Arn Anderson]], [[Brian Pillman]], and Benoit in the then-current incarnation of the [[Four Horsemen (professional wrestling)|Four Horsemen]]. [[Miss Elizabeth]] also managed the [[List of professional wrestling terms#S|stable]]. In 1996, Pillman had left the Horsemen, but they added [[Steve McMichael]] and his wife [[Debra Marshall|Debra]] in June, which didn't sit well with Woman. In her next [[List of professional wrestling terms#A|angle]], the two bickered, not getting along in general. The Four Horsemen were often given interview time on ''Nitro'' and when it came time for Debra to speak on the [[Microphone|mic]], she'd often go into a [[Monologue|soliloquy]] regarding Woman's [[Human physical appearance|looks]] and [[Fashion|fashion sense]] — usually when the two weren't within the vicinity of each other. Despite the heavy tension, the two managers never had a physical altercation. At the same time, she started an on-screen relationship with Benoit, who at the time was involved in a feud with her real-life husband, Kevin Sullivan. On December 7, on ''[[WCW Saturday Night]]'', during a post-match interview with Sullivan, a [[Home movies|home movie]] of the couple canoodling in a [[kitchen]] was played in front of him. Woman taunted Sullivan by saying, "You can't find me" and "I'm my own woman," while Benoit added: "You consider yourself the master of human [[chess]]. Well, my [[Bishop (chess)|bishop]] just took your [[Queen (chess)|queen]]". After the video, Sullivan stood there speechless, and his manager [[Jimmy Hart]] led him off stage.{{cite web|url=http://ddtdigest.com/updates/19961209.htm|title=This Week In WCW (12/07/96 – 12/09/96)|publisher=ddtdigest.com|accessdate=June 27, 2007|date=June 27, 2007}} This feud between Benoit and Sullivan saw Woman clashing with Sullivan's then-valet [[Jacqueline Moore|Jacquelyn]] at ringside. In one match, the two ladies were strapped together, took shots at each other, and used the strap connecting them as a weapon against the men. Eventually, the Benoit-Nancy on-screen relationship developed into a real-life [[affair]] off-screen. Because of this, it is often joked that 'Kevin Sullivan booked his own divorce.' The two were indeed divorced in 1997. What's more, Sullivan lost a [[Professional wrestling match types#Retirement match|retirement match]] to Benoit. His intent had been to retire from in-ring action and focus on [[List of professional wrestling terms#B|booking]]. Nancy's final WCW appearance (and professional wrestling appearance as Woman) took place on May 26, 1997 on ''Monday Nitro'' as she accompanied Benoit to the ring for a confrontation with Jimmy Hart regarding the whereabouts of Sullivan, who wasn't in the arena.{{cite web|url=http://ddtdigest.com/updates/19970526.htm|title=This Week In WCW (05/24/97 – 05/26/97)|publisher=ddtdigest.com|accessdate=June 27, 2007|date=June 27, 2007}} On the following week's show, Benoit came alone to ringside without her by his side. After managing him for a little over half a year, no reason was given for Woman's sudden disappearance, and she was never mentioned on WCW programming again.{{cite web|url=http://ddtdigest.com/updates/19970602.htm|title=This Week In WCW (05/31/97 – 06/02/97)|publisher=ddtdigest.com|accessdate=June 27, 2007|date=June 27, 2007}} ==Personal life== Before her marriage to [[Kevin Sullivan (wrestler)|Kevin Sullivan]] in 1985, Nancy had previously been married to and divorced from Jim Daus. In early 1997, while Nancy was married to Sullivan, she was having an extramarital affair with Chris Benoit. Nancy and Benoit became engaged later in 1997 after her divorce from Sullivan, although Benoit referred to Nancy as only his fiancée even after they were married. She managed her husband's career from their home in [[Atlanta, Georgia|Atlanta]]. She gave birth to their son Daniel Christopher Benoit on February 25, 2000. Nancy married Chris Benoit on November 23, 2000. However, in May 2003, she filed for divorce, citing the marriage as "irrevocably broken" and alleging "cruel treatment."{{cite news|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2007/more/06/25/wrestler.dead.ap/index.html?cnn=yes |title=WWE star killed family, self |agency=Associated Press |publisher=Sports Illustrated |accessdate=June 26, 2007 |date=June 26, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110524052903/http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2007/more/06/25/wrestler.dead.ap/index.html?cnn=yes |archivedate=May 24, 2011 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.aolcdn.com/tmz_documents/0626_benoit_dismiss.pdf|format=PDF|title=Released divorce papers and restraining order|accessdate=June 27, 2007|publisher=TMZ.com}} She dropped the suit in August 2003, as well as a restraining order filed on her husband. In December 2005, Nancy had back and neck fusion surgery with [[Lloyd Youngblood]], the same surgeon who had previously done a 3–hour neck operation on Nancy's husband Chris on June 28, 2001.{{cite web|url=http://www.onlineworldofwrestling.com/profiles/w/woman.html|title=Woman's Profile|publisher=Online World of Wrestling|accessdate=July 9, 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120525124023/www.onlineworldofwrestling.com/profiles/w/woman.html|archivedate=May 25, 2012|df=mdy-all}} After Nancy's death in 2007, ''[[Hustler]]'' published nude photographs of Nancy from a shoot taken when Nancy was 20 years old. The length of time between the events caused controversy, causing critics to claim that Hustler owner [[Larry Flynt]] was attempting to capitalize on the event. The family of Nancy Benoit took legal action against Hustler. The appellate court ruled that, "The photographs published by [Flynt] neither relate to the incident of public concern conceptually [the murders] nor correspond with the time period during which Benoit was rendered, against her will, the subject of public scrutiny".{{cite web|author= Bill Mears|url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/05/02/justice/georgia-hustler-lawsuit/index.html?iref=obnetwork |title=Family of slain wrestler loses privacy appeal over nude pictures |publisher=CNN |date=May 2, 2012 |accessdate=May 14, 2012}}{{cite web |url=http://news.gather.com/viewArticle.action?articleId=281474978076409 |title=Nancy Benoit, Hustler Photos |author= |date=March 10, 2010 |work= |publisher=News.gather.com |accessdate=August 16, 2010}}{{cite web |url=http://www.nationalledger.com/cgi-bin/artman/exec/view.cgi?archive=20&num=17946 |title=Nancy Benoit Nude Photos: Online Hustler Spread of WWE Star Chris Benoit's Wife |author=National Ledger |date=December 27, 2007 |work= |publisher=National Ledger |accessdate=August 16, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100307115054/http://www.nationalledger.com/cgi-bin/artman/exec/view.cgi?archive=20&num=17946 |archivedate=March 7, 2010 |df=mdy-all }} ==Death== {{Main|Chris Benoit double-murder and suicide}} {{Wikinewspar2|Professional wrestler Chris Benoit and family found dead|Chris Benoit mystery editor confesses: claims "terrible coincidence"}} On June 25, 2007 Benoit, her husband Chris, and their son Daniel were found dead in their home in suburban Atlanta at around 2:30 p.m.{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/sports/story/2007/06/25/wwe-benoit-obit.html|title=Canadian wrestler Chris Benoit, family found dead|accessdate=June 25, 2007|date=June 25, 2007|publisher=CBC.ca}} It first was reported by the WWE Mobile Alerts service and posted to their official website soon after. Lieutenant Tommy Pope of the Fayette County Sheriff's Department told ''[[ABC News]]'' it was being investigated as a double [[murder-suicide]],{{cite web|url=http://www.ajc.com/metro/content/metro/fayette/stories/2007/06/25/0625benoit.html|title=Pro wrestler, family found dead in Fayetteville home|author=Saeed Ahmed and Kathy Jefcoats|publisher=The Atlanta Journal Constitution|accessdate=June 25, 2007|date=June 25, 2007 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070627182538/http://www.ajc.com/metro/content/metro/fayette/stories/2007/06/25/0625benoit.html |archivedate = June 27, 2007}} and the police were not searching for any suspects outside of the house, as the instruments of death were located at the scene of the crime.{{cite web|url=http://www.abcnews.go.com/Sports/story?id=3315501&page=1|title=Wrestling Champ Chris Benoit Found Dead with Family|publisher=ABC News|accessdate=June 25, 2007|date=June 25, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071007131554/http://abcnews.go.com/Sports/story?id=3315501&page=1|archivedate=October 7, 2007}} During a press conference on June 26, Fayette County District Attorney Scott Ballard reported that Chris Benoit had killed his wife and son and committed suicide.{{cite news|title=Officials: Wrestler Strangled Wife, Suffocated Son, Hanged Self|url= http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,286737,00.html|publisher=Fox News|accessdate=June 25, 2007|date=June 26, 2007}} A [[Bible]] was left by Nancy's body, and she died of [[asphyxia]]tion.{{cite news|title=Officials: Wrestler Strangled Wife, Suffocated Son, Hanged Self|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,286737,00.html|accessdate=June 25, 2007|date=June 25, 2007 | work=Fox News}} She had bruises on her back and stomach consistent with an attacker pressing a knee into her back while pulling on a cord around her neck.{{cite news|url=http://www.ajc.com/search/content/metro/fayette/stories/2007/06/27/0627metbenoitchoke.html|title=Chokehold may have killed Benoit's son|author=Kevin Duffy|publisher=The Atlanta Journal-Constitution|accessdate=June 27, 2007|date=June 27, 2007 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070701213051/http://www.ajc.com/search/content/metro/fayette/stories/2007/06/27/0627metbenoitchoke.html |archivedate = July 1, 2007}} Daniel also died of asphyxiation, without signs of restraint. He had internal injuries to the throat area, but no bruises, indicating he may have been killed by a choke. Chris killed Nancy on Friday, Daniel on Saturday, then asphyxiated himself with the cord of a weight machine in his basement on Sunday. A memorial for Nancy and Daniel took place in [[Daytona Beach, Florida]], on July 14, 2007.{{cite web|url=http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Wrestling/Benoit/2007/07/14/4339722-ap.html|title=Service held for Nancy and Daniel Benoit|publisher=SLAM! Wrestling|accessdate=August 7, 2007|date=July 14, 2007 |archiveurl = https://archive.is/20070716175020/http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Wrestling/Benoit/2007/07/14/4339722-ap.html |archivedate = July 16, 2007}} Both were [[Cremation|cremated]] and their ashes placed in [[starfish]]-shaped [[urns]][http://www.nydailynews.com/sports/more_sports/2007/07/15/2007-07-15_wrestling_with_tragedy.html Benoit's wife and son mourned as many questions persist] for Nancy's family. Chris was also cremated,{{cite web |url=http://www.pwresource.com/495.php/2007/08/06/chris-benoit-s-body-cremated-details.html |title=Wips.com |publisher=Pwresource.com |date= |accessdate=May 14, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110715133032/http://www.pwresource.com/495.php/2007/08/06/chris-benoit-s-body-cremated-details.html |archivedate=July 15, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} but what was done with his ashes is not public knowledge. ==See also== {{Portal|Professional wrestling}} * [[Chris Benoit double-murder and suicide]] * [[The Four Horsemen (professional wrestling)|The Four Horsemen]] * [[List of premature professional wrestling deaths]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb name|0202433|Nancy Benoit}} {{Chris Benoit}} {{Four Horsemen (professional wrestling)}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Benoit, Nancy}} [[Category:1964 births]] [[Category:2007 deaths]] [[Category:American female professional wrestlers]] [[Category:Deaths from asphyxiation]] [[Category:Female models from Massachusetts]] [[Category:The Four Horsemen (professional wrestling) members]] [[Category:Murdered entertainers]] [[Category:Murdered American sportspeople]] [[Category:People murdered in Georgia (U.S. state)]] [[Category:Professional wrestlers from Massachusetts]] [[Category:Professional wrestling managers and valets]] [[Category:Sportspeople from Boston]]

[[File:Holles_Street_Hospital.JPG|thumb|Holles Street Hospital]] The '''National Maternity Hospital''', Holles Street, [[Dublin]], popularly known as '''Holles Street Hospital''', is the largest [[maternity hospital]] in [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]]. Established through charitable donations in 1894, the hospital delivers over 10,000 babies per year. It is the national referral centre for complicated pregnancies, premature and sick infants. The main hospital building at Holles Street dates to the 1930s, but the complex has seen little substantial expansion in the last half-century, while the number of births it handles has increased by 50 per cent in the last two decades.<ref name=holles>{{cite web | url=http://www.thejournal.ie/holles-street-hospital-move-st-vincents-926761-May2013/ | title=National Maternity Hospital to leave Holles St in €150m move | publisher=TheJournal.ie | date=27 May 2013 | accessdate=2013-06-18 | author=Reilly, Gavan}}</ref>
The hospital is located at the eastern corner of [[Merrion Square]], at its junction with Holles Street and Lower Mount Street.
==History== In 1903 the Hospital received a Royal Charter, as had the other maternity hospitals in Dublin. Holles Street was the first hospital to benefit from the [[Irish Hospitals' Sweepstake]] which funded extensive redevelopment in the 1930s,<ref>'Dublin since 1922' By Tim Carey, Hachette Ireland, 2016.</ref> In 1936 Antrim House on Merrion Square, was demolished to enable the development of the Hospital. Also in the 1930s the governance was altered specifying the Archbishop of Dublin (or a representative) as Chair of the board; the Lord Mayor of Dublin; and two City Councillors. The Minister of Health nominates two other members of the board.
In 1998 Holles Street set up the ''Domino'' (Domiciliary Care In and Out of Hospital) and Home birth scheme through its team of community midwives.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.eumom.ie/pregnancy/birth/preparing-for-birth/the-domino-scheme-explained|title=The Domino Scheme Explained|website=eumom.ie|access-date=28 April 2017|date=April 2017}}</ref>
List of former Masters:
1885-1893 William Roe 1894-1908 P J Barry Andrew J Horne 1909-1922 A J Horne R T White 1923 A J Horne P T McArdle 1924-1931 P T McArdle 1932-1941 J F Cunningham 1942-1948 Alex W Spain 1949-1955 Arthur P Barry 1956-1962 Charles F V Coyle 1963-1969 Kieran O’Driscoll 1970-1976 Declan J Meagher 1977-1983 Dermot W MacDonnell 1984-1990 John M Stronge 1991-1997 Peter Boylan 1998-2004 Declan Keane 2005-2011 Michael Robson 2012- Rhona Mahony. Shane Higgins has been selected to succeed Rhona Mahony in 2019.
==NMH Foundation== The National Maternity Hospital Foundation is a charity which raises funds for a number of projects in the Holles St. Hospital, with special emphasis on the neo-natal intensive care unit.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nmhfoundation.ie/about/our-mission|title=Our Mission|publisher=National Maternity Hospital Foundation|access-date=28 April 2017}}</ref> Fun runs, Golf Classics and Fashion Shows are examples of some of the events used fund raising.
==Linen Guild== The Linen Guild was established in 1912. It is a charity to help mothers and babies in extreme poverty in Dublin. Its aim in the early years was to ensure no baby left hospital without a [[layette]] of night clothes, woollen jacket, nappies and a Foxford woollen blanket. Today its aim is to raise funds, for those mothers in need of financial assistance. (see also [[Maternity package]].)
==People associated with Holles Street== [[Elizabeth O'Farrell]] a member of [[Cumann na mBan]], carried the white flag delivering the surrender in the [[Easter Rising|Easter Rising of 1916]]. She became a midwife, training and working in Holles Street. The annual award for academic excellence in midwifery is named in her honour.
The hospital is the setting for the 'Oxen of the Sun' episode of [[James Joyce]]'s novel ''[[Ulysses (novel)|Ulysses]]'' (1922).
==Controversy over involvement of the Catholic Church== In May 2013 it was announced that the hospital would relocate to the site of [[St. Vincent's University Hospital]], Elm Park, a hospital founded in 1834 on by Mother Mary Aikenhead, foundress of the order [[Religious Sisters of Charity]].<ref name=holles/>
The new hospital is projected to cost €300 million, and be paid for by the Irish state.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/opinion/peter-boylan-new-maternity-hospital-should-not-be-given-to-sisters-of-charity-1.3055744|title=Peter Boylan: New maternity hospital should not be given to Sisters of Charity|first=Peter|last=Boylan|newspaper=The Irish Times|date=21 April 2017}}</ref> The decision to give the ownership of the hospital to its founders, the Sisters of Charity (an order of [[Roman Catholic]] [[nun]]s) caused controversy.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2017/apr/20/sisters-of-charity-abuse-maternity-hospital-irish-state|newspaper=The Guardian|date=20 April 2017|first=Emer|last=O'Toole|title=The Sisters of Charity presided over abuse. They must not run a maternity hospital}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-39643164|publisher=BBC News|first=Shane|last=Harrison|date=20 April 2017|title=Anger over nuns' role in National Maternity Hospital}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/health/national-maternity-hospital-explainer-the-nuns-the-300m-in-taxpayers-money-and-the-suddenlyquiet-health-minister-35638449.html|title=National maternity hospital explainer: The nuns, the €300m in taxpayer's money, and the suddenly-quiet health minister|date=20 April 2017|newspaper=Irish Independent|first=Amy|last=Molloy}}</ref> The Sisters of Charity were involved in scandals about abuse related to the [[Magdalene Laundries in Ireland]]. The [[Citizens' Assembly (Ireland)|Citizens' Assembly]] delivered a report about the [[Eighth Amendment of the Constitution of Ireland|Eighth Amendment]] and [[Abortion in the Republic of Ireland|Irish abortion law]], and the controversy about the [[Bon Secours Mother and Baby Home]] in [[Tuam]], [[County Galway]]. This hospital transfer is being used to talk about the role of the [[Catholic Church in Ireland]] today.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The Irish Times|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/opinion/fintan-o-toole-church-control-of-hospitals-maintains-myth-of-charity-1.3059489|title=Church control of hospitals maintains myth of charity|first=Fintan|last=O'Toole|date=25 April 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The Irish Times|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/opinion/the-rt%C3%A9-campus-may-be-a-better-site-for-the-national-maternity-hospital-1.3059617|title=The RTÉ campus may be a better site for the National Maternity Hospital|first=Patsy|last=McGarry|date=25 April 2017}}</ref>
In April [[Peter Boylan|Dr. Peter Boylan]], one of Ireland's most respected obstetricians, resigned from the board over influence of the Sisters on the new hospital.<ref name=Graun/> {{As of|2017|05|03}} a petition to oppose their becoming the sole owners had been signed by more than 100,000 people.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://my.uplift.ie/petitions/block-sisters-of-chairty-as-sole-owners-of-national-maternity-hospital|title=Block Sisters of Charity as 'sole owners' of National Maternity Hospital|website=Uplift}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.newstalk.com/Petition-to-block-religious-ownership-of-National-Maternity-Hospital-exceeds-target|title=Petition to block religious ownership of National Maternity Hospital exceeds target|date=19 April 2017|first=Jack|last=Quinn|publisher=Newstalk}}</ref> A protest of 200 people took place outside the [[Department of Health (Ireland)|Department of Health]] on 20 April 2017,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/health/hundreds-protest-over-national-maternity-hospital-ownership-1.3055336|title=Hundreds protest over National Maternity Hospital ownership|date=20 April 2017|newspaper=The Irish Times|first=Sarah|last=Burns}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/this-is-an-insult-to-abuse-survivors-protesters-on-the-ownership-of-the-new-national-maternity-hospital-35639323.html|title='This is an insult to abuse survivors' - Protesters on the ownership of the new National Maternity Hospital|date=20 April 2017|newspaper=Irish Independent|first=Amy|last=Molloy}}</ref> and a protest in [[Limerick]].<ref>{{cite tweet|number=855923138365927425|title=Photos from we own #ourhospital protest in Limerick with speakers from @parents_4choice @ClareARC1 & @LmkFeminist Thanks to all who attended|user=LmkFeminist|date=23 April 2017}}</ref>
The master of the National Maternity Hospital, Rhona Mahony stated that the hospital would be independent and "the nuns will not be running this hospital, it will not be under Catholic ethos. It will be completely independent",<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The Irish Times|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/health/national-maternity-hospital-will-be-completely-independent-mahony-1.3055036|date=20 April 2017|title=National Maternity Hospital ‘will be completely independent’ - Mahony|first=Vivienne|last=Clarke}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The Irish Times|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/health/rhona-mahony-new-hospital-will-revolutionise-healthcare-for-women-and-children-1.3061805|title=Rhona Mahony: New hospital will revolutionise healthcare for women and children |first1=Vivienne|last1=Clarke|first2=Paul|last2=Cullen|first3=Mary|last3=Minihan|date=26 April 2017}}</ref> and has privately complained that "the feminists are going to unravel this fantastic hospital for women".<ref name="sunday-times-2017-03-23">{{cite news|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/bishop-says-new-hospital-must-obey-the-church-jjbgzzn86|title=Bishop says new hospital must obey the church|newspaper=The Sunday Times|page=1|date=23 April 2017|first=Justine|last=McCarthy}}</ref>
The [[Bishop of Elphin]], [[Kevin Doran]] said that the Religious Sisters of Charity would have to obey the rules of the [[Roman Catholic church]] if they become owners of the National Maternity Hospital, and to follow teachings on "the value of human life and the dignity and the ultimate destiny of the human person".<ref name="sunday-times-2017-03-23" />
On 29 May 2017, in response to weeks of pressure and public outrage, the Sisters of Charity announced that they were ending their role in St Vincent's Healthcare Group and would not be involved in the ownership or management of the new hospital; the two sisters on the board resigned.<ref name=Graun>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/may/29/sisters-of-charity-nuns-give-up-role-in-dublin-maternity-hospital |title=Sisters of Charity give up role in Dublin maternity hospital |newspaper=The Guardian |date=29 May 2017 |author= Henry McDonald |accessdate= 29 May 2017}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Twelvers}} The '''Deputies or Wikalah''' was a social, religious and economic institution that was active from [[Ja'far al-Sadiq]]'s time to end of the [[Minor Occultation]] until 941 CE. Wikalah was responsible for the made relation between imams and Shia and collect religious taxes. ==Terminology== The meaning of word wikalah that mean of ours is wikalah in Arabic means to let someone perform duties on behalf of someone especially when someone cannot accomplish his duties by himself. In the other hands, wikalah in terms of jurisprudence is someone choose someone else as his agent who that someone has the right to interfere in Decision making and approving a Duty or to be the second person who can interfere in His affairs. After the above definition, it can be seen that the wikalah are used when a person is unable to perform his duties by himself for reasons such as position and necessities and Imamas could not communicate with Shia by direct and usual ways.<ref name="al-islam"/> ==History== The Shia Imams frequently had to deal with persecution and sometimes resorted to the practice of taqiyya, a form of religious dissimulation, for protection <ref>{{cite book |last1=Illahi |first1=Mahboob |title=Doctrine of Terror: Saudi Salafi Religion |publisher=FriesenPress (October 2, 2018) |isbn=978-1525526466 |page=176-177|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6w9xDwAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=Doctrine+of+Terror:+Saudi+Salafi+Religion&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjbkpz5ruLeAhVGKuwKHfN1DDsQ6AEIJzAA#v=onepage&q=Doctrine%20of%20Terror%3A%20Saudi%20Salafi%20Religion&f=false}}</ref>. According to the critical situation of the Imams in this era,Imams was looking for a way to make connection with shia.Often deputies were acting Secretly from the Abbasid Caliphs and in some cases, they did not know that they were deputies of the Imams and work for them. <ref name="Jassim M.">{{cite book |last1=Hussain |first1=Jassim M. |title=The Occultation of the Twelfth Imam (A Historical Background) |publisher=CreateSpace Independent Publishing Platform (October 12, 2014) |isbn=978-1502797506 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=w7LNoAEACAAJ&dq=The+Occultation+of+the+Twelfth+Imam+(A+Historical+Background)&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiJ9InQkeDeAhWHmbQKHVFwBpoQ6AEIJzAA}}</ref> ===Formation=== The network of agents (Wikalah) was established in the time of [[Ja'far al-Sadiq]] and during the time was being Organized as far as it reached to the peak of its efficiency in the time of [[Hasan al-Askari]]<ref name="q">{{cite encyclopedia |last=Robson |first=J. |title=Isnād |url=http://referenceworks.brillonline.com/entries/encyclopaedia-of-islam-2/isnad-SIM_3665?s.num=0&s.q=Isn%C4%81d&s.f.s2_parent_title=Encyclopaedia+of+Islam%2C+Second+Edition |editor1-last=Bearman |editor1-first=P. |editor2-last=Bianquis |editor2-first=Th. |editor3-last=Bosworth |editor3-first=C.E. |editor4-last=van Donzel |editor4-first=E. |editor5-first=W.P. |editor5-last=Heinrichs |date=13 April 2010 |encyclopedia=Encyclopaedia of Islam |edition=Second |publisher=Brill Online. Augustana |doi=10.1163/1573-3912_islam_SIM_3665 |isbn=978-900416121-4 |access-date=6 June 2018 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180612144713/http://referenceworks.brillonline.com/entries/encyclopaedia-of-islam-2/isnad-SIM_3665?s.num=0&s.q=Isn%C4%81d&s.f.s2_parent_title=Encyclopaedia+of+Islam%2C+Second+Edition |archivedate=12 June 2018 |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> and then minor occultation.<ref name="al-islam">{{cite web |last1=Jabbari |first1=Mohammad Reza |title=Preparing the Shi'a for the Age of Occultation Part 2 |url=https://www.al-islam.org/message-thaqalayn/vol-11-no-1-spring-2010/preparing-shia-age-occultation-part-2-mohammad-reza |publisher=Ahlul Bayt World Assembly}}</ref>The function of this system is shown in letters of instruction of the [[Al-Hadi]].According to Jassim M. Hussain and [[Abdulaziz Sachedina]], deputies were responsible for managing the society.<ref name="q"/><ref name="Jassim M."/> Jassim M. Hussain said: "Gradually the leadership of the Wikalah became the only authority which could determine and prove the legitimacy of the new Imam."
For example, the ninth Imam, al‑Jawad said to the head of his deputies about installing Al-Hadi as next Imam. <ref name="Jassim M."/> ===Minor occultation=== {{main|The Four Deputies}} The Four Deputies or Gates ({{lang-ar|أبواب}})<ref>[[Encyclopaedia Iranica]] (2011). [http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/bab-door-gate-entrance BĀB (1)]</ref>, in [[Twelver]] [[Shia Islam]], were the four individuals who served as messengers between the community and the [[Muhammad al-Mahdi|twelfth and final Imam]], upon his going into the [[Minor Occultation]]. The deputies are also referred to with the Arabic terms Safir (emissary), Na'ib (deputy)<ref>{{cite book|editor1-last=Fitzpatrick|editor1-first=Coeli|editor2-last=Walker|editor2-first=Adam Hani|title=Muhammad in History, Thought, and Culture: An Encyclopedia of the Prophet of God [2 volumes]|date=2014|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=9781610691789|page=644|edition=illustrated}}</ref> or Wakil (advocate).<ref>{{cite book|author1=Mohammad Ali Amir-Moezzi|title=Divine Guide in Early Shi'ism, The: The Sources of Esotericism in Islam|publisher=SUNY Press|isbn=9780791494790|page=100}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=The Essence of Islam|date=2012|publisher=Concept Publishing Company|isbn=9788180698323|page=195}}</ref>
Twelver tradition holds that four deputies acted in succession to one another from 873–941 CE:
# [[Uthman ibn Sa’id al-Asadi]] († 873-80) # [[Abu Jafar Muhammad ibn Uthman|Abu Jafar Muhammad ibn Uthman ibn Sa’id al-Asadi]] († 917) # [[Abul Qasim Husayn ibn Ruh al-Nawbakhti]] († 938) # [[Abul Hasan Ali ibn Muhammad al-Samarri]] († 941)
The [[Major Occultation]] began following the death of the last deputy and, according the Shia doctrine, will continue until the return of the [[Mahdi]]. ==Duties== Wikalah were responsible to made the relation between imams and Shia and collect religious taxes ([[Khums]], [[Zakat]], etc.).<ref>{{cite book |last1=Hussain |first1=Jassim M. |title=The Occultation of the Twelfth Imam (A Historical Background) |publisher=CreateSpace Independent Publishing Platform (December 6, 2013) |isbn=978-1494350987 |page=29 |url=https://books.google.com/books/about/The_Occultation_of_the_Twelfth_Imam.html?id=ilfYAAAAMAAJ}}</ref><ref name="m">{{cite book |last1=Sachedina |first1=Abdulaziz Abdulhussein |title=Islamic Messianism: The Idea of the Mahdi in Twelver Shi'ism |publisher=SUNY Press; 1st edition (June 1, 1981) |isbn=978-0873954587 |url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Islamic_Messianism.html?id=csmpQgAACAAJ&source=kp_book_description}}</ref> But next to it were responsible to guide the Shia and delivered letters containing religious questions. More importantly, they were responsible for the introduction of the next Imam after the death of the previous Imam.<ref name="al-islam"/>
==See also== {{Portal|Shia Islam|Islam}} * [[Ali al-Hadi]] * [[Muhammad al-Mahdi]] *[[Sayyid Ali Akbar]] * [[List of extinct Shia sects]] * [[Muhammad ibn Ali al-Hadi]] * [[Muhammadite Shia]] * [[Imamate (Twelver doctrine)]] * [[Ahl Al-Bayt]] * [[Jafar ibn Ali al-Hadi]] ==References== {{reflist}}

{{short lead|date=December 2017}} {{refimprove|date=December 2017}} {{Infobox comics character |image=orrgo.jpg |image_size=200 |caption=Orrgo on the cover to ''[[Strange Tales]]'' #1, art by [[Jack Kirby]] |character_name=Orrgo |real_name= |publisher=[[Marvel Comics]] |debut=''[[Strange Tales]]'' vol. 1 #90 (Nov 1961) |creators=[[Jack Kirby]] |alliances=[[S.H.I.E.L.D.]]
[[Nick Fury's Howling Commandos|Howling Commandos]]
[[S.T.A.K.E.]] |aliases= |powers=Great mental powers |}} '''Orrgo''' is a fictional character appearing in [[American comic book]]s published by [[Marvel Comics]]. ==Publication history== {{expand section|date=December 2017}} Orrgo first appeared in ''[[Strange Tales]]'' vol. 1 #90 and was created by [[Jack Kirby]].{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} As part of the ''[[All-New, All-Different Marvel]]'', Orrgo appears in ''[[Howling Commandos of S.H.I.E.L.D.]]''{{cite web|url=http://www.comicvine.com/articles/frank-barbiere-and-brent-schoonover-talk-about-shi/1100-152826/|title=Frank Barbiere & Brent Schoonover Talk About S.H.I.E.L.D.'s Dirty Little Secret and the HOWLING COMMANDOS|publisher=}} ==Fictional character biography== Orrgo is a 25–30 ft. [[Extraterrestrial life in popular culture|extraterrestrial]] "space god", who arrived on Earth and has tried to conquer it many times in the past. He arrived on Earth to display his superior powers over the humans. With his abilities, Orrgo took over the world quickly. With the human race under his mental domination, Orrgo went back to the circus where it first arrived and went to sleep. A circus gorilla named Jojo realized that it was the reason that it was not being fed. Jojo escaped from its cage and killed Orrgo. The human race was then freed from Orrgo's control as the rest of Orrgo's kind left thinking that the humans have defeated Orrgo.''Strange Tales'' #90 The [[Headmen]] later stole the God from Beyond from the museum and used it to summon Orrgo.''Defenders'' Vol. 2 #5 The [[Headmen]] and [[MODOK]] summoned Orrgo using the God from Beyond statue. [[Patsy Walker|Hellcat]], [[Nighthawk (Marvel Comics)|Nighthawk]], and [[Valkyrie (Marvel Comics)|Valkyrie]] of the [[Defenders (comics)|Defenders]] fought Orrgo only to be defeated by him. Orrgo then went on to attack the city. After making volcanoes erupt, cities levitate, and populated areas burst into flames, Orrgo took control of the minds of Earth's population. The Headmen, MODOK, and the Defenders were not affected because they came in contact with the God from Beyond.''Defenders'' Vol. 2 #9 When the Defenders attacked the Headmen's base, they ordered Orrgo to summon a supervillain army to fight them. While [[Doctor Strange]], [[Hulk (comics)|Hulk]], [[Namor]], and [[Silver Surfer]] were busy fighting the villains, Hellcat, Nighthawk, and Valkyrie enter the base of the Headmen as Nighthawk seized the God from Beyond. With the God from Beyond in their possession, the Defenders ordered Orrgo to undo the damage that it caused. With the damage undone and the supervillains teleported back to where they came from, Doctor Strange stated that they could banish all evil from Earth. Hellcat broke the God from Beyond stating that it would be a violation of the free will to do such a thing. Upon being freed, Orrgo thought for itself again and threatened to devastate the planet. Hellcat reminded Orrgo that his race has always been defeated by the humans and asked if he really wanted to fight them. Orrgo decides to leave Earth and return when the humans are extinct.''Defenders'' Vol. 2 #10 Through unknown means, Orrgo was captured by [[S.H.I.E.L.D.]] and placed in the [[Nick Fury's Howling Commandos|Howling Commandos]] Monster Force.''Nick Fury's Howling Commandos'' #6 Orrgo appears as a member of [[S.T.A.K.E.]], a S.H.I.E.L.D. division dealing with the supernatural. His commander is [[Dum Dum Dugan]], who lives on in a highly advanced Life Model Decoy body.{{issue|date=January 2016}} As part of the ''[[All-New, All-Different Marvel]]'' event, Orrgo appears as a member of S.T.A.K.E.'s Howling Commandos. Due to Orrgo's enormous size, he is not a field member of the team, but is used as technological support and communications. He enjoys chaotic events. Despite the very nature of many of his teammates, Orggo does not believe in the supernatural.''[[Howling Commandos Of S.H.I.E.L.D.]]'' #1–3 (2015) During the ''[[Avengers: Standoff!]]'' storyline, Orrgo was an inmate of Pleasant Hill, a gated community established by S.H.I.E.L.D.''Avengers Standoff: Assault on Pleasant Hill Alpha'' #1 It is later revealed that Orrgo ended up in Pleasant Hill after Dr. Paul Kraye caught him going through his files. He alerted Maria Hill claiming that Orrgo went rogue and Orrgo was imprisoned at Pleasant Hill, where he was turned into a dog by Kobik. This led the Life Model Decoy of Dum Dum Dugan into finding Pleasant Hill and leading the Howling Commandos there in order to rescue Orrgo. Orrgo is rescued as the group is transported back to S.T.A.K.E. HQ by Kobik. Once back at S.T.A.K.E. HQ, Orrgo detects that Paul Kraye has released all the inmates there.''Howling Commandos of S.H.I.E.L.D.'' #6 Orrgo was with the Howling Commandos at the time when they help [[Old Man Logan]] rescue [[Jubilee (comics)|Jubilee]] from [[Dracula (Marvel Comics)|Dracula]].''Old Man Logan'' Vol. 2 #14-15 During the ''[[Monsters Unleashed (comics)|Monsters Unleashed]]'' storyline, Orrgo is among the monsters that helped to fight the Leviathon Tide.''Monsters Unleashed'' Vol. 2 #3 ==Powers and abilities== {{expand section|date=December 2017}} Aside from his superhuman strength, Orrgo has great mental powers that seem to alter reality. He also possesses powerful lungs as he was able to blow people off their feet. He also seems to have some manner of freezing abilities. ==Other versions== ===Marvel Adventures=== In the ''[[Marvel Adventures]]'' continuity, Orrgo is shown to be roughly the size of the [[Thing (comics)|Thing]] and continually boasts that he has "amazing mental powers". Immediately after a battle with the [[Fantastic Four]], Orrgo gains diplomatic immunity and shows up to judge a beauty contest where he proceeds to get into an argument with Ben over their terms of 'beauty'. Eventually [[Invisible Woman|Sue]] discovers through one of the contestants, Chili Storm, that the security team are actually agents of [[Advanced Idea Mechanics|A.I.M.]] and are looking to steal Orrgo's technology. The Four aid Orrgo in battling the agents before being stopped by Orrgo's powers. Orrgo then orders the agents to get jobs at a fast food restaurant, which [[Human Torch|Johnny]] calls cruel. Afterwards, Chili chooses to go out with Orrgo which he considers his revenge on Ben from an earlier fight.''Marvel Adventures: Fantastic Four'' #35 == In other media == === Video games === Orrgo appears as a boss and recruitable character in the mobile game ''[[Marvel Avengers Academy]]'' during the limited ''Monsters Unleashed!'' event, voiced by Scott Montiel.{{Cite news|url=https://www.voices.com/people/scottm#feedbacks|title=Scott Montiel|last=Voices.com|work=Voices.com|access-date=2017-03-15|language=en}} Writer Allen Warner praised his "goofy, crazy, over-the-top attitude and power set that make[s] him a great fit for the game, and perfect for an event that features a [[Devil Dinosaur|red dinosaur]] fighting a [[Fin Fang Foom|dragon from outer space]]".{{cite web|url=https://news.marvel.com/games/60727/monsters-unleashed-upon-marvel-avengers-academy/|title=Monsters Unleashed Upon 'Marvel Avengers Academy'|last=Snyder|first=Justin|date=2017-03-02|website=Marvel.com|publisher=|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-03-15}} ==Notes== * [[Adam Able]]'s home planet was called '''Orrgo''' in ''Journey into Mystery'' vol. 1 #82. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[http://marvel.wikia.com/wiki/Orrgo_%28Earth-616%29 Orrgo] at Marvel Wiki *{{Marvunapp|http://www.marvunapp.com/Appendix/orrgopre.htm}} {{Howling Commandos}} [[Category:Characters created by Jack Kirby]] [[Category:Comics characters introduced in 1961]] [[Category:Fictional extraterrestrial characters]] [[Category:Fictional monsters]] [[Category:Howling Commandos]] [[Category:Male characters in comics]] [[Category:Marvel Comics aliens]] [[Category:Marvel Comics characters with superhuman strength]] [[Category:Marvel Comics characters who have mental powers]] [[Category:Marvel Comics superheroes]]

'''Pamela Theodora Weston''' (17 October 1921 – 9 September 2009) was a [[United Kingdom|British]] [[clarinet]]ist, teacher and writer.
Born in London, she attended Priors Field School. Following two years at the [[Royal Academy of Music]] she won a scholarship to the [[Guildhall School of Music]] before studying privately with the noted clarinetist [[Frederick Thurston]]. She was a professor of clarinet at the Guildhall from 1951 until 1969. She organised the International Clarinet Association Congress in 1984, the first ever held in the [[United Kingdom]].
Weston's legacy continues in the form of a scholarship for clarinet research at doctoral level, available from the [[Royal College of Music]], recognising the institution's pre-emininence in this area, across both practice and theory.
==Publications== Her first book, ''Clarinet Virtuosi of the Past'', published in 1971, was followed by ''The Clarinet Teacher's Companion'' (1976), ''More Clarinet Virtuosi of the Past'' (1977), ''Clarinet Virtuosi of Today'' (1989) and ''Yesterday's Clarinettists: A Sequel'' (2002). Weston also published numberous articles in professional journals associated with the clarinet, both in the UK and abroad.
==Death== Suffering in her last years from debilitating [[myalgic encephalomyelitis]], she travelled to [[Switzerland]] to undertake an assisted suicide at the age of 87 in 2009.<ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/pamela-weston-clarinettist-music-historian-and-inspirational-teacher-1807577.html Obituary in ''The Independent'']</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Authority control}}
