revision.comment: /* Story */ Actually, it's already been confirmed that Evice and Nascour are arrested at the end of the game.
revision.text:
{{good article}} {{Infobox video game | title = Pokémon Colosseum | image = Pokémon Colosseum Coverart.png |alt=A teenage boy with grey hair and a blue jacket stands in the background, looking menacingly at the camera. In the foreground are several large creatures: a red robot-like wingless dragon, a blue robot-like whale, and three dogs with classical visual motifs of fire, ice, and electricity. Superimposed on the scene is the bulky text "Pokémon Colosseum". | caption = North American cover art. Clockwise from top: Wes, [[Kyogre]], [[Raikou]], [[Suicune]], [[Entei]], and [[Groudon]]. | developer = [[Genius Sonority]] | publisher = [[Nintendo]]
[[The Pokémon Company]] | director = Manabu Yamana | producer = Gakuji Nomoto
Hiroyuki Jinnai
Hiroaki Tsuru
Kenji Miki
[[Shigeru Miyamoto]] | designer = Kazunori Orio
Gakuji Nomoto
Akihiko Miura
Sayaka Yamazaki
Ryota Aomi
Chiharu Sugaya
Kōji Ōno | programmer = Masayuki Kawamoto | artist = Sin'Ichi Hiromoto | writer = Kazunori Orio | composer = [[Tsukasa Tawada]] | released = {{vgrelease|JP|November 21, 2003|NA|March 22, 2004|EU|May 14, 2004}} | genre = [[Role-playing video game|Role-playing]] | series = ''[[Pokémon (video game series)|Pokémon]]'' | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]], [[multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] | platforms = [[GameCube]] }} '''''Pokémon Colosseum'''''{{efn|{{nihongo|ポケモンコロシアム||Pokemon Koroshiamu}}}} is a [[role-playing video game|role-playing]] [[video game]] developed by [[Genius Sonority]], published by [[The Pokémon Company]] and distributed by [[Nintendo]] as part of the ''[[Pokémon (video game series)|Pokémon]]'' series. It was released for the [[GameCube]] on November 21, 2003, in Japan; March 22, 2004, in North America; and May 14, 2004, in Europe. Unlike previous titles, the game does not feature [[random encounter]]s with Pokémon; instead, the player can steal ("snag") the Pokémon of other [[Pokémon Trainer]]s. The game also features several battle modes for [[single-player video game|single-player]] and [[multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] gameplay. The game is set in the desertous region of Orre. The [[player character|player]] protagonist is Wes, a former member of [[Pokémon crime syndicates#Team Snagem|Team Snagem]]. Throughout the game, the player rescues "Shadow Pokémon"—Pokémon who have had their hearts darkened by [[Pokémon crime syndicates#Team Cipher|Team Cipher]], an antagonistic organization—via snagging. Rui, a [[non-player character]], serves as Wes's sidekick and identifies Shadow Pokémon. ''Pokémon Colosseum'' was exhibited at [[History of the Electronic Entertainment Expo|E3 2003]]. North American pre-orders were packaged with a bonus disc that allows the player to download the Pokémon [[Jirachi]]. Upon release, the game was generally well-received, with praise directed at its graphics and music. It was a commercial success, with 1.15 million copies sold in the United States and 656,270 in Japan. ==Gameplay== {{further|Gameplay of Pokémon}} [[File:PokemonColosseumBattle.JPG|thumb|left|The player battles with [[Sudowoodo]] and [[Hitmontop]], who are both identifiable as Shadow Pokémon by the purple border of their avatars. This battle against the opponent's [[Trapinch]] and [[Numel]] is conducted on Mt. Battle, a common setting for battles.]] ''Pokémon Colosseum'' is a [[3D computer graphics|3D]] [[role-playing video game|role-playing]] game viewed from a [[third-person (video games)|third-person]] perspective. The player, controlling a [[Pokémon Trainer]] named Wes (default name), moves through various towns and other locations (traversed using a type of one-wheeled motorcycle), battling enemy Trainers and completing quests. Items are purchased at "Pokémon Mart" locations using the game's currency, "Pokémon Dollars" ([[File:Pokébuck sign.png]]). When a battle starts, the screen switches to a [[time-keeping systems in games|turn-based]] interface where the player's and enemies' Pokémon fight. Most battles are of the "double battle" format, which means two Pokémon on each side at one time. However, each Trainer can carry up to six Pokémon at one time, so once a Pokémon is defeated, his or her Trainer must switch out another one unless no more are left. Battles are also conducted at "Colosseums" in several cities.{{cite web|title=Pokemon Colloseum Update|url=http://cube.ign.com/articles/490/490107p1.html|publisher=IGN|date=February 4, 2004|author=IGN Staff|accessdate=November 20, 2010}} Unlike most ''[[Pokémon (video game series)|Pokémon]]'' games, ''Colosseum'' does not feature [[random encounter]]s. The player begins the game with two Pokémon. More are obtained throughout the game by "Snagging" them from other Trainers using [[Poké Ball]]s of various strengths. Only specifically designated "Shadow Pokémon", whose hearts have been artificially closed, can be Snagged. Pokémon can be traded between ''Colosseum'' and the [[Game Boy Advance]] games [[Pokémon Ruby and Sapphire|''Pokémon Ruby'', ''Sapphire'']], [[Pokémon FireRed and LeafGreen|''FireRed'', ''LeafGreen'']], or ''[[Pokémon Emerald|Emerald]]''. Each of the player's Shadow Pokémon has a purple gauge that is drained by battling and coming to like the player. Once a Pokémon's gauge is empty, the player may "Purify" the Pokémon by bringing him or her to [[Celebi (Pokémon)|Celebi]]'s shrine in Agate Village, or by using a rare "Time Flute" item. Purifying Shadow Pokémon is desirable because while in that status, they will often disobey the player, they cannot gain [[experience point]]s, and their moves are at first restricted to "Shadow Rush".{{cite web|title=Pokémon Colosseum|url=http://cube.gamespy.com/gamecube/pokemon-colosseum/502636p1.html|publisher=[[GameSpy]]|date=March 29, 2004|last=Vassar|first=Darryl|accessdate=August 2, 2010}} Additionally, Shadow Pokémon will sporadically enter "Hyper Mode" state during battle, causing them to disobey the player character or attack themselves until the condition is alleviated by selecting the "Call" battle command. Aside from the story mode, ''Colosseum'' also features several non-canonical battle modes. In the "Quick Battle" mode, the player can battle either CPU trainers or friends, using Pokémon obtained in the story mode or randomly assigned ones. Battles in this mode do not result in gain of experience points or money. In the [[single-player video game|single-player]] battle mode, the player competes at Colosseums—stadiums used throughout the game for Pokémon battles—and earns "Poké Coupons", another currency which can be used to buy rare items. In the "Gang Battle" mode, up to four players can compete in a tournament. The first can use Pokémon obtained in the story mode, or from the Game Boy Advance games. Players two through four, however, can only use Pokémon from the Game Boy Advance games. ==Plot== [[File:OrreMap.PNG|thumb|300px|''Pokémon Colosseum''{{'}}s 3D [[overworld]] features visual detail and a fixed camera angle that is comparable to Square Enix's ''[[Final Fantasy]]'' series. Shown here is Es Cade's office. Characters of various significance clockwise from top left: Verde, Trudly, Folly, Miror B. (with afro), Wes, Rui, Bluno, and Rosso.|alt=A dim mayor's office on the first floor of a small building features a brown carpet, red sofas, a large television with the news on, and an unoccupied, large desk with a black vinyl chair. A staircase in the back leads out of the room. The teenage boy, and a teenage girl with orange hair and a denim jacket, are standing near the unseen front door. In the center of the room stand three men wearing red, blue, and green full-body suits, as well as two more wearing punk attire. These men are centered around a taller man sporting a red and white afro about three feet in diameter; he is turned away from the teenage boy and girl.]] ===Setting=== ''Pokémon Colosseum'' is set in the Orre region. Orre is a mostly desertous region in which no wild Pokémon can be found (although the sequel, ''Pokémon XD: Gale of Darkness'', adds wild Pokémon spots to the region). Orre consists of many cities, towns, and Colosseums.{{cite web|title=Pokémon Colosseum Preview|url=http://www.gamespot.com/gamecube/strategy/pokemoncolosseum/news.html?sid=6091502&mode=previews|publisher=GameSpot|last=Torres|first=Ricardo|date=March 15, 2004|accessdate=July 1, 2010}} ===Characters=== The game's [[player character|player]] protagonist is by default named {{nihongo|Wes|レオ|Reo|Leo}}, but as with most ''Pokémon'' games, the player can change his name. Wes's [[Gameplay of Pokémon#Starter Pokémon|Starter Pokémon]] are [[Espeon and Umbreon]], two cat Pokémon who start at higher levels than most Starter Pokémon.{{cite web|title=Pokemon Colosseum - GC - Review|url=http://gamecube.gamezone.com/reviews/item/pokemon_colosseum_gc_review|publisher=GameZone|date=March 23, 2004|accessdate=June 16, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69wEmReG5?url=http://www.gamezone.com/reviews/pokemon_colosseum_gc_review|archivedate=August 15, 2012|df=}} {{nihongo|Team Snagem|スナッチ団|Sunatchi-dan|Snatch Gang}}, a [[Pokémon crime syndicates|criminal organization]] that uses the "Snag machine" technology to capture the Pokémon of Trainers, serves as an antagonistic entity in the game.{{cite video game|title=Pokémon Colosseum|developer=[[Genius Sonority]]|year=2004|quote='''Newscaster:''' TEAM SNAGEM is a gang of POKéMON abductors who have already been marked for arrest.}} However, shortly after the game's start, {{nihongo|Team Cipher|シャドー団|Shadō-dan|Shadow Gang}} is revealed to be the main antagonistic force, having partnered with Snagem to obtain Pokémon from Trainers, corrupting them, and distributing them throughout Cipher and other places such as Pyrite Town. Wes is a former employee of Team Snagem. The organization also employs many grunt workers, as well as four administrators: [[disco]]-loving {{nihongo|Miror B.|ミラーボ|Mirābo|Mirorbo}}, the explosively-tempered bodybuilder, {{nihongo|Dakim|ダキム|Dakimu}}, the queen of the Under, {{nihongo|Venus|ヴィーナス|Vīnasu}}, and the strategist of a scientist, {{nihongo|Ein|ボルグ|Borugu|Borg}}.{{cite web|title=Pokemon Colosseum Review|url=http://www.gamespot.com/gamecube/strategy/pokemoncolosseum/review.html|date=March 22, 2004|last=Davis|first=Ryan|publisher=[[GameSpot]]|accessdate=April 1, 2010}} ===Story=== The game begins with a [[cold open]] in which Wes infiltrates and destroys the Team Snagem hideout before leaving the organization.{{cite video game|title=Pokémon Colosseum|developer=Genius Sonority|year=2004|quote='''Newscaster:''' The HIDEOUT was discovered only as a result of the explosion. By the time police arrived, the ruined building had already been abandoned.}} Wes starts at the Outskirt Stand, a dilapidated train engine in the middle of the desert that has been converted into a shop. With Espeon and Umbreon, Wes's first opponent is a Trainer named Willie.{{cite video game|title=Pokémon Colosseum|developer=Genius Sonority|year=2004|quote='''Willie:''' Yo! Wait! Wait up! Hey, my name's WILLIE. After I got a good look at you, well, I got this urge to battle you. It's like I'm compelled to. Any way I look at it, it's obvious that you're no ordinary Joe. So what do you say? Let's you and me have a quick battle!}} Wes then leaves the Stand and heads to the [[oasis]]-esque Phenac City in time to see two men dragging a sack.{{cite video game|title=Pokémon Colosseum|developer=Genius Sonority|year=2004|quote='''Trudly:''' Yeah, you say that, but this... It won't stop squirming. Makes it tough to hold on.}} After defeating them in battle, Wes unties the sack to find Rui,{{cite video game|title=Pokémon Colosseum|developer=Genius Sonority|year=2004|quote='''Rui:''' Phew! Thank goodness! I'm saved! ...Where is this? Where did those two bring me?}} a girl with the ability to discern Shadow Pokémon. They meet the mayor, Es Cade,{{cite video game|title=Pokémon Colosseum|developer=Genius Sonority|year=2004|quote='''Es Cade:''' Ah, you must be travelers! Welcome to PHENAC CITY! I am ES CADE, the MAYOR.}} who seems very bothered about the Cipher problem, but seems to do nothing about it.{{cite video game|title=Pokémon Colosseum|developer=Genius Sonority|year=2004|quote='''Rui:''' I saw a peculiar POKéMON... No, that's not quite right. What I saw was a POKéMON that gave off a black aura. It was like a fighting machine! And, that POKéMON could attack people! / '''Es Cade:''' O-o-o-oh, my! POKéMON like a fighting machine? And it attacks people?! Now, if that were true, that would be truly frightening. However, it is a little hard to believe.}} Later, upon leaving Phenac Colosseum, three Snagem grunts find Wes and Rui. The grunts then reveal to Rui that he was a member of Snagem, and an excellent Snagger.{{cite video game|title=Pokémon Colosseum|developer=Genius Sonority|year=2004|quote='''Grunt:''' But he's no ordinary member. He's a SNAGGER. He's the best in TEAM SNAGEM at Snagging POKéMON without fail!}} Wes then confronts one of the grunts, which results in the latter's defeat. Finding out that he is an expert at snagging Pokémon, Rui asks him to join forces with her in finding and snagging Shadow Pokémon. As the game progresses, Wes becomes a target of a powerful organization known as Team Cipher. After leaving Phenac, he visits Pyrite Town, where Rui was kidnapped. In Pyrite, Shadow Pokémon are openly offered to winners of the town's Colosseum tournament. The local police force is powerless to stop the practice, so Duking, an influential man in Pyrite, asks Wes to enter the tournament and investigate. Wes enters the Colosseum challenge and defeats four trainers to win. Inside a nearby building, a Cipher [[Peon]] is about to present the Shadow Pokémon prize, but another one recognizes Wes. The pair then battle their way through the building and a maze-like cave set in the rock behind. Eventually, they face and defeat Miror B., one of four Cipher Admins. Afterwards, Wes returns a Pokémon Miror B. stole from Duking. A team of kids working in Duking's house introduce themselves as members of an anti-Cipher news network, known as the Kids Grid, who pledge their help to Wes and Rui. Their next stop is Agate Village, a forested village in the mountains. As Rui introduces Wes to her grandfather Eagun, another villager runs into the room, telling them that the Relic Stone—a shrine protected by [[Celebi (Pokémon)|Celebi]]—is under attack. Wes, following Eagun to the center of the tree, fights off four Cipher agents before the Relic Stone is safe. After resting, Wes is given access to the Relic Stone, the only place where he can purify Shadow Pokémon. After receiving an e-mail from Duking about Mt. battle being under attack by Cipher, Rui asks Eagun where it is and the two headed over there. Upon reaching Mt. Battle, people inform Wes and Rui that Cipher has already taken over the first section of the mountain. After battling nine other Trainers, Wes battles the Cipher administrator Dakim. Dakim owns a Shadow [[Entei]], who is one of the trio of legendary beasts. After defeating Dakim, Wes heads to The Under, which is an underground city located underneath Pyrite Town, and under the control of Cipher. More members of the Kids Grid are here. They tell the player of Venus, another Cipher administrator, who has influence over The Under. After Wes confronts Venus, the owner of the second legendary beast [[Suicune]], she flees. Next, Wes and Rui head to the Shadow Pokémon Lab, where Pokémon are transformed into Shadow Pokémon. After defeating numerous Cipher [[peon]]s, Wes faces Ein, the final Cipher administrator and the owner of the final legendary beast [[Raikou]]. Wes and Rui then go to Realgam Tower. All four administrators are there and ready to face Wes again. After doing so, he is granted access to the Colosseum at the top of the building. There, he is greeted by a large crowd. A Cipher man named Nascour tells Wes that he will have to face four trainers. After Wes defeats all four trainers, Nascour fights him. Once defeated, Nascour tries to leave, only to be interrupted by Es Cade. Es Cade reveals that he is really none other than Evice, the head of Cipher, and battles Wes. When Wes defeats him, Evice attempts to escape by helicopter, but the legendary Pokémon [[Ho-Oh]] swoops in and blasts it out of the sky. Evice and Nascour are sent to jail. ==Development and release== ''Pokémon Colosseum'' was developed by the Japanese game developer [[Genius Sonority]], and published by [[Nintendo]]. Just as [[Nintendo 64]] predecessors ''[[Pokémon Stadium]]'' and ''[[Pokémon Stadium 2]]'' had served as home console counterparts to the [[Pokémon#Generations|first- and second-generation]] handheld titles, ''Colosseum'' had a similar role for the third generation.{{cite web|title=Got Shadow Pokémon?|url=http://www.rpgamer.com/games/pokemon/pokecol/pokecolprev.html|publisher=RPGamer|last=Harwood|first=Justin|accessdate=August 18, 2010}} The new concept for ''Pokémon Colosseum'' was influenced by RPGs such as ''[[Final Fantasy VII]]'' and ''[[Persona 2 (disambiguation)|Persona 2]]'' over the ''Pokémon'' mold. When asked in an interview with [[Prima Games]] why the gameplay of ''Colosseum'' did not mirror that of the handheld ''Pokémon'' games, ''Pokémon'' director [[Junichi Masuda]] explained: "How players communicate with each other has been key to the ''Pokémon'' games – it is the backbone of all ''Pokémon'' game designs. I feel that the handheld systems work better than the home-based consoles. It's certainly possible to come up with concepts for home-based consoles, but we might then have to change the core of the game."{{cite book|title=Pokédex: Collector's Edition|year=2004|publisher=[[Prima Games]]|last=Mylonas|first=Eric|page=222|isbn=0-7615-4761-4}} [[File:PhoenixDowntown.jpg|left|thumb|The city of [[Phoenix, Arizona]] was primarily used as the basis for the Orre region.]] The transition to 3D also brought new graphical changes. Wes was designed to look "hazy" and about 17 years old.{{cite web|script-title=ja:「新しいことをしよう」でスペシャリストたちがぞくぞく集結|url=https://www.nintendo.co.jp/nom/0311/soft/interv01.html|publisher=Nintendo.co.jp|accessdate=February 10, 2011|language=Japanese}} Genius Sonority ported most of the models and animations of first- and second-generation Pokémon from ''Stadium'' and ''Stadium 2''. Genius Sonority based most of Orre on the real-life city of [[Phoenix, Arizona]]. As a whole, the graphics were influenced more by [[manga]] than by established ''Pokémon'' convention. A preview for the game was hosted at [[History of the Electronic Entertainment Expo|E3 2003]].{{cite web|title=Pokémon Colosseum E3 2003 Preshow Report|url=http://www.gamespot.com/gamecube/strategy/pokemoncolosseum/news.html?sid=6027654&mode=previews|last=Calvert|first=Justin|publisher=[[GameSpot]]|date=May 13, 2003|accessdate=January 29, 2010}} Upon completion of development, ''Colosseum'' received a rating of "E" (Everyone) from the [[Entertainment Software Rating Board]], "All Ages" from [[Computer Entertainment Rating Organization]], and "3+" from [[Pan European Game Information]]. The game was released on November 21, 2003 in Japan; March 22, 2004 in North America, and May 14, 2004 in Europe.{{cite web|title=Pokemon Colosseum for GameCube|url=http://www.gamespot.com/gamecube/strategy/pokemoncolosseum/similar.html?mode=versions|publisher=[[GameSpot]]|accessdate=January 29, 2010}} Nintendo also published supplementary media to unlock additional content. Pre-ordered copies of the game came with a bonus disc that contains trailers for the game and the film ''[[Pokémon: Jirachi Wish Maker]]''. The North American disc also contains the exclusive Pokémon [[Jirachi]] that can be downloaded to the player's copy of ''Ruby'' or ''Sapphire''. The Japanese release contains a downloadable Celebi instead and requires a completed save file of Pokémon Colosseum. The disc also updates the software in ''Ruby'' and ''Sapphire'' to remove a "berry glitch" discovered in 2003. Despite public anticipation the Bonus Disc was not released in PAL territories, prompting Nintendo to issue an official apology.{{cite web|title=Jirachi|url=http://gameboy.ign.com/articles/491/491109p1.html|last=Harris|first=Craig|publisher=IGN|authorlink=Craig Harris|date=February 9, 2004|accessdate=April 6, 2010}} However a Jirachi was later included in the PAL version of the game [[Pokémon Channel]]. In Japan, scannable cards for the [[Nintendo e-Reader]] were available for purchase that featured additional trainers to battle and Shadow Pokémon.{{cite web|title=Pokemon Cards Set for Christmas|url=http://cube.ign.com/articles/441/441992p1.html|publisher=IGN|date=November 24, 2003|author=IGN Staff|accessdate=March 19, 2011}}{{cite web|title=Free memory card with Pokémon Colosseum!|url=http://www.computerandvideogames.com/article.php?id=102503|publisher=Computer and Video Games|date=March 17, 2004|accessdate=August 14, 2010}} ==Reception== ===Critical response=== {{Video game reviews | GR = 73.46% | MC = 73/100 | Allgame = {{rating|3.5|5}} | CVG = 9/10{{cite web|title=Pokemon Colosseum Review|url=http://www.computerandvideogames.com/article.php?id=103687&skip=yes|publisher=[[Computer and Video Games]]|author=CVG Staff|date=April 26, 2004|accessdate=June 17, 2010}} | Fam = 33/40''Point Plus 30: ポケモンコロシアム''. Famitsū. No.1153. Pg.40. 20 January 2011. | GamePro = 70% | GSpot = 7.3/10 | GSpy = {{rating|3|5}} | GameZone = 8.5/10 | IGN = 7.5/10 | NP = 94% | rev1 = Gamers Hell | rev1Score = 7.9/10 }} ''Pokémon Colosseum'' was generally well-received upon release, with respective scores of 73/100 and 73.46% from aggregators [[Metacritic]] and [[GameRankings]].{{cite web|title=Pokemon Colosseum for GameCube|url=http://www.gamerankings.com/gamecube/914973-pokemon-colosseum/index.html|publisher=[[GameRankings]]|accessdate=April 14, 2010}}{{cite web|title=Pokemon Colosseum|url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/gamecube/pokemon-colosseum|publisher=[[Metacritic]]|accessdate=April 4, 2010}} [[Allgame]] staff writer Scott Alan Marriott gave the game three and a half stars out of five, although he did not review the game with more depth.{{cite web|title=Pokémon Colosseum|url=http://www.allgame.com/game.php?id=43549|publisher=[[Allgame]]|last=Marriott|first=Scott Alan|accessdate=May 12, 2010}} Critics praised ''Colosseum'' as the first true 3D role-playing installment in the ''Pokémon'' series. Gamers Hell reviewer John K. called it "certainly a step in the right direction to a good 3D ''Pokémon'' game", although he felt that the limited number of Pokémon and lack of a true [[overworld]] detracted from the experience.{{cite web|title=Pokemon Colosseum Review|url=http://www.gamershell.com/gamecube/pokemon_colosseum/review.html|publisher=Gamers Hell|author=John K.|accessdate=October 11, 2010}} [[IGN]] staff writer Craig Harris said that the adaptation of the ''Pokémon'' RPG formula to the 3D zeitgeist "does a decent enough job" and is "a bit more linear and straightforward".{{cite web|title=Pokemon Colosseum|url=http://cube.ign.com/articles/500/500909p1.html|last=Harris|first=Craig|authorlink=Craig Harris|date=March 22, 2004|accessdate=April 1, 2010|publisher=IGN}} The new 3D graphics received mixed remarks. Harris called the game "[g]raphically ... a mixed bag", praising the visual style of the game's Pokémon but criticizing the "poorly modeled and animated, angular" style of the Trainers. [[GameSpot]] reviewer Ryan Davis offered a similar opinion, concluding that "[t]he visual style ... has gone off the deep end". ''[[GamePro]]'' writer Star Dingo called the graphics as a whole "insanely cute" but criticized the lack of animations showing two Pokémon attacking in tandem.{{cite web|title=Pokemon Colosseum|last=Dingo|first=Star|date=April 22, 2004|publisher=''[[GamePro]]''|url=http://www.gamepro.com/article/reviews/35148/pok-mon-colosseum/|accessdate=June 16, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http://www.gamepro.com/article/reviews/35148/pok-mon-colosseum/&date=2011-12-01+05:22:42|archivedate=2011-12-01}} GameZone's review took a more positive stance, saying that "[a]nimations are brief but impressive; each attack move is more elaborate and more extravagant on the 'Cube." ''[[Nintendo Power]]'' thought similarly, commending the "amazing level of detail".{{cite magazine|magazine=[[Nintendo Power]]|title=Pokémon Colosseum|page=119|date=May 2004|issue=179}} GameZone compared the overall town design and environments to those of the landmark ''[[Final Fantasy VII]]''. Dingo complained that "there are some characters to talk to and chests to find, but no 'overworld' with free-roaming monsters to capture." John K. stated that "[t]he towns are made with enough detail, but sometimes a bit dull." Harris denounced the game's usage of old Pokémon battle cries, a recurring complaint of the series. Dingo called the music as a whole "a bit too low-tech and synthetic". GameZone, in contrast, stated that the sound effects evoke nostalgia for [[Pokémon Red and Blue|''Pokémon Red'' and ''Blue'']], and that the music tracks "have more depth than any of the songs from the previous {{sic|Poke|mon}} games." John K. said that the music is neither annoying nor entertaining. [[Retronauts]] described ''Colosseum'' as "terrible", citing the reuse of graphics from the ''Pokémon Stadium'' games.{{cite web|title=Retronauts|url=http://www.podtrac.com/pts/redirect.mp3/podcast.the1upnetwork.com/flat/Retronauts/R030611.mp3|publisher=[[1UP Shows and Podcasts]]|accessdate=March 10, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6E9wUJBlg?url=http://podcast.the1upnetwork.com/flat/Retronauts/R030611.mp3|archivedate=February 3, 2013|df=}} In 2006, ''Nintendo Power'' listed ''Colosseum'' as the 121st greatest video game to appear on a Nintendo console.{{cite magazine|magazine=Nintendo Power|title=Pokémon Colosseum|issue=200|date=February 2006}} ===Sales=== Three weeks before its release, pre-orders of ''Pokémon Colosseum'' made it the best-selling game on [[Amazon.com]].{{cite web|title=Pokemon Colosseum Already Racking Up Sales|url=http://www.nintendoworldreport.com/news/9386|publisher=[[Nintendo World Report]]|date=March 6, 2004|last=Bloodworth|first=Daniel|accessdate=August 18, 2010}} In the game's first week of release in the United Kingdom, it boosted the GameCube's market share from 16% to 32%.{{cite web|title=Pokémon Colosseum Doubles 'Cube's Share|url=http://www.computerandvideogames.com/article.php?id=105917|publisher=Computer and Video Games|last=Houlihan|first=John|date=June 11, 2004|accessdate=August 14, 2010}} It was the best-selling GameCube game of May 2004, and fourteenth among all consoles.{{cite web|title=ChartSpot: May 2004|url=http://www.gamespot.com/gamecube/strategy/pokemoncolosseum/news.html?sid=6101516&mode=news|publisher=GameSpot|date=June 28, 2004|last=Thorsen|first=Tor|accessdate=July 1, 2010}} In 2005, the game was certified as part of Nintendo's [[Player's Choice]] line in North America, representing at least 250,000 copies sold. As of 2007, the game has sold over 1.15 million copies in the United States{{cite web|url=http://www.the-magicbox.com/Chart-USPlatinum.shtml|title=US Platinum Videogame Chart|publisher=The Magic Box|date=December 27, 2007|accessdate=April 6, 2010}} and 656,270 in Japan.{{cite web|url=http://www.japan-gamecharts.com/gc.php|title=Nintendo Gamecube Japanese Ranking|publisher=Japan Game Charts|date=May 6, 2007|accessdate=April 6, 2010}} It is the best-selling RPG for the GameCube.{{cite web|title=Pokemon Report: World Records Edition|url=http://ds.ign.com/articles/946/946074p1.html|publisher=IGN|date=January 16, 2009|last=DeVries|first=Jack|accessdate=March 19, 2011}} ===Legacy=== ''Pokémon Colosseum'' spawned a high-profile tournament in the United Kingdom entitled "Pokémon Colosseum Battlemaster 2004". The first round of battles was held at [[Toys "R" Us]] locations, with later battles taking place in [[movie theater]]s.{{cite web|title=Pokémon Colosseum Battlemaster 2004 competition!|url=http://www.computerandvideogames.com/article.php?id=103463|publisher=Computer and Video Games|date=April 19, 2004|accessdate=August 14, 2010}} Across Europe, the game was bundled with GameCube consoles shortly after its release.{{cite web|title=Exclusive: Pokémon Colosseum GC bundle for Europe!|url=http://www.computerandvideogames.com/article.php?id=102340|publisher=Computer and Video Games|date=March 11, 2004|accessdate=August 14, 2010}} Special editions of this set also included a copy of ''[[Pokémon Box: Ruby and Sapphire]]'' —a game that allows players to organize and store up to 1,500 Pokémon from their games—as well as a memory card and a Game Boy Advance–GameCube link cable.{{cite web|title=Pokemon Colosseum and Box Pak|url=http://cube.ign.com/articles/506/506548p1.html|publisher=IGN|date=April 14, 2004|author=IGN Staff|accessdate=March 19, 2011}} A [[manga]] adaptation of ''Colosseum''{{'}}s plot was printed in 2004 issues of the Japanese magazine ''[[CoroCoro Comic]]'' and titled {{nihongo|''Pokémon Colosseum Snatcher Leo''|ポケモンコロシアムスナッチャーズレオ}}.{{cite journal|script-title=ja:スペシャルコミック: スナッチャー・レオ|journal=[[CoroCoro Comic]]|language=Japanese|date=January 2004|page=26}} The game was followed by a 2005 sequel entitled ''[[Pokémon XD: Gale of Darkness]]''. Set in Orre five years after ''Colosseum'', it features a new protagonist snagging Shadow Pokémon from Team Cipher. Shadow [[Lugia]] is the game's mascot, and serves as an antagonist whom the player can snag.{{cite web|title=Pokemon XD: Gale of Darkness Review|url=http://www.gamespot.com/gamecube/rpg/pokemongc/review.html|publisher=GameSpot|date=October 10, 2005|last=Mueller|first=Greg|accessdate=March 7, 2011}} The game alludes to Wes, Rui, and The Under, though they do not appear.{{cite video game|title=Pokémon XD: Gale of Darkness|developer=Genius Sonority|year=2005|quote='''Old man:''' There once was a town ruled by CIPHER beneath the cliff here. The town was just called THE UNDER. When CIPHER's hold over the town was broken, the UNDER citizens moved out into the sunlight. I'm one of them. ONBS's NETT is another former resident of THE UNDER. They went and buried THE UNDER to prevent people from getting to the abandoned town site. It's sad to see my hometown go like that.}} ==See also== {{portal|Pokémon|2000s|Video games}} *''[[Pokémon XD: Gale of Darkness]]'' *''[[Pokémon Battle Revolution]]'' {{-}} ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://register.nintendo.com/gamemini?gameid=m-Game-0000-1847 ''Pokémon Colosseum''] at [[Nintendo.com]] ([https://web.archive.org/web/*/http://www.nintendo.com/gamemini?gameid=m-Game-0000-1847 archives] of the [https://web.archive.org/web/20071012013618/http://www.nintendo.com/gamemini?gameid=m-Game-0000-1847 original] at the [[Internet Archive]]) {{Pokémon}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pokemon Colosseum}} [[Category:Role-playing video games]] [[Category:GameCube games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Japan]] [[Category:GameCube-only games]] [[Category:Genius Sonority games]] [[Category:Pokémon RPGs|Colosseum]] [[Category:Multiplayer and single-player video games]] [[Category:2003 video games]]

{{Infobox baseball biography |image=Rob dibble motion 1991.jpg |name=Rob Dibble |position=[[Pitcher]] |bats=Left |throws=Right |birth_date={{birth date and age|1964|1|24|mf=y}} |birth_place=[[Bridgeport, Connecticut]] |debutleague = MLB |debutdate=June 29 |debutyear=1988 |debutteam=Cincinnati Reds |finalleague = MLB |finaldate=September 30 |finalyear=1995 |finalteam=Milwaukee Brewers |statleague = MLB |stat1label=[[Win–loss record (pitching)|Win–Loss record]] |stat1value=27–25 |stat2label=[[Earned run average]] |stat2value=2.98 |stat3label=[[Strikeout]]s |stat3value=645 |stat4label=[[Save (baseball)|Saves]] |stat4value=89 |teams= * [[Cincinnati Reds]] ({{mlby|1988}}–{{mlby|1993}}) * [[Chicago White Sox]] ({{mlby|1995}}) * [[Milwaukee Brewers]] ({{mlby|1995}}) |highlights= * 2× [[Major League Baseball All-Star Game|All-Star]] ([[1990 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|1990]], [[1991 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|1991]]) * [[World Series]] champion ({{wsy|1990}}) * [[NLCS MVP]] ([[1990 NLCS|1990]]) }} '''Robert Keith Dibble''' (born January 24, 1964) is an American former [[Major League Baseball]] (MLB) [[pitcher]] and television analyst. Between 1988 and 1995, Dibble played for the [[Cincinnati Reds]], [[Chicago White Sox]] and [[Milwaukee Brewers]]. He was a two-time [[Major League Baseball All-Star Game|All-Star]] who recorded 89 [[Save (baseball)|saves]] during his career. Since retiring as a player, Dibble has held several roles in sports television broadcasting.
==Personal life== Dibble was born in [[Bridgeport, Connecticut]]. He attended St. Thomas School, a [[parochial school]], and is a graduate of [[Southington High School]] in [[Southington, Connecticut]]. Dibble's father, Walt Dibble, was a longtime radio news director at [[WDRC-FM|WDRC]] and later [[WTIC (AM)|WTIC]] in [[Hartford, Connecticut]].
==Playing career==
===Cincinnati Reds=== Dibble was drafted by the [[Cincinnati Reds]] in the first round of the 1983 amateur draft, and he made his debut with the Reds on June 29, 1988.
On June 4, 1989, Dibble struck out three batters on nine pitches in the eighth inning of a 5–3 win over the [[San Diego Padres]]. Dibble is one of 41 pitchers in Major League history to accomplish the [[Pitchers who struck out three batters on nine pitches|nine-pitch/three-strikeout half-inning]], a feat known as an immaculate inning.
He was an [[Major League Baseball All-Star Game|MLB All-Star]] in [[1990 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|1990]] and [[1991 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|1991]], and was the [[1990 National League Championship Series|1990 NLCS]] [[Most Valuable Player]] (along with fellow "[[Nasty Boys (Cincinnati Reds)|Nasty Boy]]" [[Randy Myers]]). In 1990, Dibble and the [[1990 Cincinnati Reds season|Reds]] won the [[1990 World Series|World Series]] by beating the [[1990 Oakland Athletics season|Oakland Athletics]] in four consecutive games.
Dibble recorded his 500th career strikeout in fewer innings—368—than any other pitcher in modern baseball history up to that point (a record that is currently held by [[Craig Kimbrel]]).
====Temper==== During his career Dibble was known for his temper. During a game in July 1989, he hit [[1989 New York Mets season|Mets]] second basemen [[Tim Teufel]] in the back with a pitch; Teufel then [[charging the mound|charged]] Dibble, causing a benches clearing brawl. After saving a game in April 1991 despite giving up two runs in relief, Dibble threw a baseball 400 feet into the center-field seats at Cincinnati, inadvertently striking a woman.<ref name=4May1991port>{{cite news|title=National League suspends Dibble for 4 games for firing ball into stands|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=hkRGAAAAIBAJ&sjid=P9EMAAAAIBAJ&pg=2876,369254|accessdate=19 April 2011|newspaper=[[Portsmouth Daily Times]]|date=4 May 1991}}</ref><ref name=nyt4May1991>{{cite news|title=A New Suspension for Reds' Dibble|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/04/sports/baseball-a-new-suspension-for-reds-dibble.html|accessdate=19 April 2011|newspaper=[[New York Times]]|date=4 May 1991}}</ref><ref name="truebaseballstories">{{cite book|last=Shannon|first=Mike|title=Tales from the Dugout: The Greatest True Baseball Stories Ever Told|year=1998|publisher=McGraw-Hill|isbn=0-8092-2950-1|page=60|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=y17fnEHFIcsC&pg=PA60&lpg=PA60&dq=rob+dibble+temper&source=bl&ots=jtWuseI7dN&sig=FKTLECwOrf_nNGQC6vsZHQHIUv4&hl=en&ei=p0T4S7-TLoKdlgedntnECg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CB0Q6AEwAjgK#v=onepage&q=rob%20dibble%20temper&f=false}}</ref> He was also involved in a brawl in 1991 with [[1991 Houston Astros season|Astros]] shortstop [[Eric Yelding]].<ref name=nyt4May1991 /><ref name="spartanburg">{{cite news|title=Dibble, Yielding suspended|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1876&dat=19910418&id=OuoeAAAAIBAJ&sjid=NM4EAAAAIBAJ&pg=5474,749743|accessdate=22 May 2010|newspaper=Spartanburg Herald-Journal|date=April 18, 1991}}</ref> Later in the 1991 season, he threw a baseball into the back of [[1991 Chicago Cubs season|Cubs]] outfielder [[Doug Dascenzo]] as he ran down the first base line and was subsequently ejected from the game.<ref name="nytimes_july261991">{{cite news|last=Vescey|first=Peter|title=Sports of The Times; Rob Dibble: The Pitcher Most Likely|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/26/sports/sports-of-the-times-rob-dibble-the-pitcher-most-likely.html|accessdate=22 May 2010|newspaper=New York Times|date=July 26, 1991}}</ref> Dibble also was involved in a brawl with manager [[Lou Piniella]] in the Reds clubhouse after a game in 1992.<ref name="la_times1992">{{cite news|title=Piniella, Dibble Brawl in Clubhouse|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1992-09-18/sports/sp-723_1_major-league|accessdate=22 May 2010|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=September 18, 1992}}</ref>
===Later career=== Dibble required surgery to his pitching arm in 1994, and missed the entire season as a result. Dibble signed with the [[1995 Milwaukee Brewers season|Milwaukee Brewers]] and also played with the [[1995 Chicago White Sox season|Chicago White Sox]]. He signed with the [[1995 Chicago Cubs season|Chicago Cubs]] at the end of the 1995 season, but voluntarily retired from the team the following March after a rough spring. Weeks later, he opted to make a comeback, signing a minor league contract on April 14, 1996 with the [[1996 Florida Marlins season|Florida Marlins]],<ref name="sunsentinel_apr171996">{{cite news|last=O'Brien|first=David|title=Marlins Taking A Chance On Dibble|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1996-04-17/sports/9604160589_1_dibble-marlins-reliever-matt-mantei|accessdate=6 March 2018|newspaper=Sun-Sentinel|date=April 17, 1996}}</ref> but Dibble would ultimately see no game action with the Marlins or their minor league affiliates.
==Broadcasting career== [[File:Rob Dibble 2009.jpg|thumb|Dibble with the Nationals in 2009.]] In 1998, Dibble joined [[ESPN]] as a [[baseball]] analyst, working mostly on [[Dan Patrick]]'s radio show. He worked on ''[[The Best Damn Sports Show Period]]'' as a co-host until 2008, when he left to join FOX on their Saturday baseball program as an analyst. Dibble also spends time as a co-host/analyst of First Pitch on [[XM]] Channel 175/Sirius channel 210. He formerly hosted ''The Show'' (on the same channel) with [[Jody McDonald]]. Dibble served as co-analyst (with [[Kevin Kennedy (baseball)|Kevin Kennedy]]) for [[FOXSports.com]] on a weekly video segment entitled "Around the Bases." Dibble also is a co-host with former Major League player [[Denny Hocking]] on Fox Sports Radio Sunday night programming. In 2009, Dibble signed a three-year contract to replace [[Don Sutton]] as the color voice of the [[Washington Nationals]] on [[MASN]].<ref>[http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2009/apr/06/on-masn-dibble-wont-be-so-nasty/ Dibble not so 'nasty']. Washington Times (2009-04-06). Retrieved on 2011-06-09.</ref>
While broadcasting a game in August 2010, Dibble drew negative attention for focusing on a group of female spectators in the Nationals crowd, and questioning their focus on the game.<ref name="washpostWomen">{{cite news|last=Steinberg|first=Dan|title=Rob Dibble amazed by women at baseball game |url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/dcsportsbog/2010/08/rob_dibble_amazed_by_women_at.html|work=D.C. Sports Bog – Washington Post Online|authorlink=Dan Steinberg|accessdate=2 September 2010}}</ref><ref name=siWomen>{{cite news|last=Heyman|first=Jon|title=Daily Scoop|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2010/writers/jon_heyman/09/02/daily.scoop/ |work=Sports Illustrated|accessdate=19 April 2011|date=2 September 2010}}</ref> He later apologized for the comments.<ref name=espnwaiver>{{cite web|title=Stephen Strasburg needs 2nd MRI|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/mlb/news/story?id=5497876|work=ESPN.com|accessdate=19 April 2011}}</ref> Later in the month, Dibble criticized Nationals rookie pitcher [[Stephen Strasburg]] for missing a start due to an injury: "Suck it up, kid. This is your profession. You chose to be a baseball player. You can't have the cavalry come in and save your butt every time you feel a little stiff shoulder, sore elbow."<ref name=espnwaiver /><ref name=steinbergStrass>{{cite news|authorlink=Dan Steinberg|last=Steinberg|first=Dan|title=Rob Dibble to Stephen Strasburg: "Suck it up"|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/dcsportsbog/2010/08/rob_dibble_to_stephen_strasbur.html|work=D.C. Sports Bog – [[Washington Post]]|accessdate=19 April 2011}}</ref> It was revealed shortly afterward that Strasburg had torn an elbow ligament and required [[Tommy John surgery]].<ref name=wpostShapiro>{{cite news|last=Shapiro|first=Leonard|title=Should Rob Dibble be fired for his comments about Stephen Strasburg?|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/08/31/AR2010083102266.html?sid=ST2010090100278|accessdate=19 April 2011|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|date=31 August 2010}}</ref><ref name="dibble_gone">{{cite news|last=Kilgore|first=Adam|title=Rob Dibble no longer broadcasting Nationals games|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/nationalsjournal/2010/09/rob_dibble_no_longer_broadcast.html|work=Nationals Journal – Washington Post Online|accessdate=1 September 2010}}</ref> Dibble took a few days off from [[MASN]] after making the comments, and on September 1, 2010, MASN announced that Dibble would no longer be calling Nationals games.<ref name=dibble_fired>{{cite news|last=duLac|first=J. Freedom|title=Washington Nationals fire TV announcer Rob Dibble after his comments about Stephen Strasburg|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/09/01/AR2010090106482.html?hpid=topnews|accessdate=20 April 2011|newspaper=[[Washington Post]]|date=2 September 2010}}</ref><ref name="mlb_stras">{{cite web|title=TV analyst Dibble won't make road trip|url=http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20100829&content_id=14063466&notebook_id=14064924&vkey=notebook_mlb&fext=.jsp&c_id=mlb|publisher=MLB.com|accessdate=30 August 2010}}</ref><ref name=espnnolonger>{{cite web|title=Rob Dibble no longer working for Nats|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/mlb/news/story?id=5521129|publisher=ESPN.com|accessdate=19 April 2011}}</ref> After losing his job with the Nationals, Dibble apologized for the Strasburg comments on his radio show.<ref name=steinberg2Sep2010>{{cite news|authorlink=Dan Steinberg|last=Steinberg|first=Dan|title=Rob Dibble talks about leaving MASN|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/dcsportsbog/2010/09/rob_dibble_on_leaving_masn.html|work=D.C. Sports Bog – [[The Washington Post|WashingtonPost.com]]|accessdate=15 April 2011}}</ref>
In April 2011, Dibble said in an interview on [[FoxSports.com]] that the reason for his dismissal was because of an email Strasburg's father sent to the [[Ted Lerner|Lerner Family]], the owners of the Nationals.<ref name=usatoday7Apr2011>{{cite news|last=White|first=Paul|title=Rob Dibble thinks Stephen Strasburg's dad cost him his job|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/dailypitch/post/2011/04/rob-dibble-think-stephen-strasburgs-dad-cost-him-his-job/1|accessdate=15 April 2011|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|date=7 April 2011}}</ref> Dibble also continued to express his belief that Strasburg should have pitched through his pain.<ref name=msnbc7Apr>{{cite web|last=Calcaterra|first=Craig|title=Rob Dibble still thinks Stephen Strasburg should have "sucked it up|url=http://hardballtalk.nbcsports.com/2011/04/07/rob-dibble-still-thinks-steven-strasburg-should-have-sucked-it-up/|work=[[msnbc]]|accessdate=19 April 2011}}</ref><ref name=wpKilgore15Apr>{{cite news|last=Kilgore|first=Adam|title=Stan Kasten: Rob Dibble’s account of his firing ‘fictional’ and ‘sad’|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/nationals-journal/post/stan-kasten-rob-dibbles-account-of-his-firing-fictional-and-sad/2011/04/08/AFGySm3C_blog.html|work=Nationals Journal – [[The Washington Post|WashingtonPost.com]] blog|accessdate=15 April 2011|date=8 April 2011}}</ref> Strasburg denied the claim about his father's e-mail, and [[Stan Kasten]], the president of the Nationals, called Dibble's account "fictional" and "sad".<ref name=wpKilgore15Apr /><ref name=short_9Apr>{{cite web|last=Short|first=D.J.|title=We have a war of words between Stan Kasten and Rob Dibble|url=http://hardballtalk.nbcsports.com/2011/04/09/we-have-a-war-of-words-between-stan-kasten-and-rob-dibble/|work=[[msnbc]]|accessdate=19 April 2011}}</ref> As of October 31, 2011, Dibble became a member of Mike North's talk radio show.
Dibble had a brief stint as the varsity baseball head coach at [[Calabasas High School]] in [[Calabasas, California]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.calabasasbaseball.net/teams/default.asp?u=CALABASASBASEBALL&t=c&s=baseball&p=coaches |title=Staff |publisher=Calabasasbaseball.net |date= |accessdate=2012-10-18}}</ref> He was fired from his head coaching job on March 27, 2013, only ten games into the season.<ref>https://sports.yahoo.com/blogs/highschool-prep-rally/rob-dibble-high-school-baseball-head-coaching-career-170736285.html</ref> As of December 18, 2013, he, along with [[Amy Van Dyken]], were replaced on [[Fox Sports Radio|Fox Sports Radio's]] ''Fox Sports Tonight''.
Dibble currently calls [[Los Angeles Angels]] games for [[Compass Media Networks|Compass Media]].<ref>http://hardballtalk.nbcsports.com/2013/03/27/rob-dibble-fired-as-high-school-coach-after-10-games/</ref>
On March 27, 2014, Dibble became the host of the 3–7 pm (Eastern) sports talk show on WUCS 97.9 FM and WAVZ 1300 AM in the ESPN stations in Hartford and New Haven, CT respectively. He joined interim host Paul Nanos who filled in when Mike Bower's contract was not renewed. Up until the end of October the show was billed as ''The Rob Dibble Show with Paul Nanos''. In October, the show was renamed ''The Rob Dibble Show''.[26]
==See also== *[[List of Major League Baseball all-time saves leaders]]

{{about|the satirical group|the 1993 political party|Canada Party|the 2015 political party|Canada Party (2015)}} <!-- Don't mess with this line! --> <!-- Write your article below this line -->
{{Infobox political party | name = The Canada Party | native_name = | native_name_lang = | abbreviation = | logo = | colorcode = red<!-- guess --> | leader = Chris Cannon and Brian Calvert | president = | chairman = | secretary = | spokesperson = | foundation = 2012 <!-- {{start date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | founder = | dissolved = | slogan = America, But Better | ideology = [[Satire]] and [[Politics]] | headquarters = Vancouver, British Columbia | international = | website = {{url|www.americabutbetter.com}} | country = Canada }}
'''''The Canada Party''''' is a political satire group devoted to electing Canada as President of the United States. Founded in [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]], in 2012, the organization produces and shares a variety of satirical media, including videos, posters, memes, and various campaign material. In 2012, they published the Canadian bestseller, ''[https://www.amazon.com/dp/1771000627 America, But Better]''
==Critical reception== The Canada Party's inaugural video,<ref>{{cite web|title=Meet the Canada Party|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BrhA0sEkuaM}}</ref> has received more than one million views, and was described by ''[[George Stroumboulopoulos Tonight]]'' as "one of the top political ads of the 2012 election."<ref>{{cite web|title=George Stroumboulopoulos Tonight|url=http://www.cbc.ca/strombo/politics-2/best-of-2012-our-top-5-political-ads-of-the-year.html}}</ref> Subsequent [http://www.americabutbetter.com/#!videos/c129n videos] have tallied more than 80 million additional views.
The 2012 campaign was featured by outlets such as CNN,<ref>{{cite web|title=CNN|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rqN_nXee4-I}}</ref> CBC, BBC, the Rush,<ref>{{cite web|title=The Rush|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=i1UQqdfC-v8&list=PL7C2F7E71AA017D80&index=13}}</ref> and German State Television. C-SPAN produced a half-hour special on a campaign rally at the [[KGB Bar]] in [[New York City]].<ref>{{cite web|title=C-SPAN campaign coverage|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gXYqf7Wh2w4&index=14&list=PL7C2F7E71AA017D80}}</ref>
==Book== ''[http://www.douglas-mcintyre.com/book/america-but-better America, But Better: the Canada Party Manifesto]'' was published in August, 2012 by Douglas & MacIntyre. The book was a Canadian bestseller, with [[Publishers Weekly]] claiming of the authors "their bite is on par with that of the Daily Show, Steven Colbert, and Bill Maher."<ref>{{cite web|title=Publishers Weekly|url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/978-1-77100-062-8}}</ref>
==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.thecanadaparty.com/}}
==References== {{reflist}} <!-- After listing your sources please cite them using inline citations and place them after the information they cite. Please see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:REFB for instructions on how to add citations. --> * * * *
<!-- STOP! Be warned that by using this process instead of Articles for Creation, this article is subject to scrutiny. As an article in "mainspace", it will be DELETED if there are problems, not just declined. If you wish to use AfC, please return to the Wizard and continue from there. -->
{{DEFAULTSORT:Canada Party, The}} [[Category:Joke political parties]] [[Category:Political parties established in 2012]]
{{fictional-stub}}
